programs.name: 2-1-1 Bay Area
programs.description: Free 24/7 referral to food, housing, legal help, health care, and more
programs.fullDescription: 2-1-1 Bay Area is a free, confidential helpline connecting residents to essential community services 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, in over 180 languages.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free 24/7 helpline (dial 2-1-1)
- Referrals to food assistance programs
- Housing and shelter resources
- Legal help connections
- Health care navigation
- Utility assistance referrals
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Dial 2-1-1 from any phone
2. Or visit 211bayarea.org
3. Speak with trained specialist
4. Describe your needs
5. Receive personalized referrals
6. Follow up on resources provided

programs.name: CZI Community Space
programs.description: Free meeting and event spaces for select local nonprofits including rooms for up to 150 people, coworking areas, A/V equipment, and kitchen access
programs.fullDescription: The Chan Zuckerberg Initiative Community Space provides free meeting and event venues for local nonprofits at their Redwood City headquarters, supporting community organizations with professional facilities.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free meeting rooms for up to 150 people
- Coworking areas available
- Full A/V equipment included
- Kitchen access for events
- Professional event support
- Multiple room configurations
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a San Mateo County nonprofit
2. Submit application through CZI website
3. Describe your organization and event needs
4. Wait for approval from CZI team
5. Schedule your space once approved
6. Follow facility guidelines for events

programs.name: Dolly Parton Imagination Library
programs.description: Free book mailed monthly to child's home for kids (up to age 5); high-quality, age-appropriate books selected by experts; builds home library of up to 60 books by kindergarten
programs.fullDescription: Dolly Parton's Imagination Library sends a free, high-quality book every month to registered children from birth to age five, building home libraries and fostering early literacy across California.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free book mailed monthly
- For children birth to age 5
- High-quality, age-appropriate books
- Selected by early childhood experts
- Build library of up to 60 books
- Delivered directly to your home
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit California State Library website
2. Enter your child's information
3. Provide mailing address
4. Register each eligible child separately
5. First book arrives within 8-10 weeks
6. Books continue monthly until age 5

programs.fullDescription: Generation Thrive, a partnership between the Golden State Warriors and Kaiser Permanente, provides free meeting and workspace to Bay Area nonprofits at their state-of-the-art facility.

- Full A/V equipment included

2. Submit space request online
3. Describe your organization and needs

programs.name: Season of Sharing Fund
programs.description: Emergency rental and basic needs assistance to prevent homelessness

4. Show risk of homelessness

1. Visit MEDA office in the Mission
2. Complete intake assessment
3. Meet with career coach
4. Enroll in training programs
5. Receive ongoing job search support
programs.address: 2301 Mission St, Suite 301, San Francisco, CA 94110

programs.name: Immigration Institute of the Bay Area
programs.description: Affordable immigration legal services and consultations
programs.fullDescription: The Immigration Institute of the Bay Area (IIBA) provides affordable immigration legal services to immigrant families throughout the Bay Area.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Low-cost immigration legal consultations
- Citizenship and naturalization assistance
- Green card and family petition services
- DACA renewal support
- Deportation defense referrals
- Legal workshops and Know Your Rights
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Call IIBA to schedule appointment
2. Complete intake and eligibility screening
3. Attend consultation with immigration specialist
4. Receive case assessment and options
5. Proceed with legal services if eligible
programs.address: 1063 Market St, Suite 400, San Francisco, CA 94103

programs.name: East Bay Community Law Center - Immigration
programs.description: Free immigration legal representation for low-income Alameda County residents
programs.fullDescription: East Bay Community Law Center provides free immigration legal services to low-income immigrants in Alameda County, including representation and community education.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free immigration legal consultations
- Representation in immigration court
- Asylum application assistance
- Family-based petitions
- Naturalization and citizenship
- Community education workshops
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Call EBCLC intake line
2. Complete screening for services
3. Must be low-income Alameda County resident
4. Attend appointment with immigration attorney
5. Receive representation or referrals

programs.name: SF Homelessness and Supportive Housing
programs.description: Emergency shelter, navigation centers, and permanent housing assistance
programs.fullDescription: San Francisco's Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing (HSH) coordinates the city's response to homelessness, providing shelter, housing, and supportive services.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Emergency shelter access
- Navigation centers with services
- Permanent supportive housing
- Rapid rehousing assistance
- Street outreach teams
- Connection to services
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Call SF Homeless Outreach Team at 415-734-4233
2. Or call 311 for shelter information
3. Connect with street outreach if unsheltered
4. Complete intake at navigation center
5. Receive housing and service referrals

programs.name: Project Homeless Connect
programs.description: Free one-stop access to services, care coordination, and housing navigation
programs.fullDescription: Project Homeless Connect organizes community events and ongoing services connecting people experiencing homelessness with essential resources and care.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Large community resource events
- Ongoing care coordination
- Free haircuts and hygiene items
- Medical and dental care referrals
- Legal services
- Benefits enrollment assistance
- Housing navigation
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Attend Project Homeless Connect events
2. Visit their service hub for ongoing support
3. Access free services without appointment
4. Connect with case managers
5. Receive referrals to housing and benefits

programs.name: St. Anthony's Free Dining Room
programs.description: Free nutritious meals served daily with dignity to anyone in need
programs.fullDescription: St. Anthony's operates San Francisco's largest free dining room, serving nutritious meals daily to anyone in need without questions or requirements.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free hot meals daily
- No ID or documentation required
- Vegetarian options available
- Served with dignity and respect
- Clean, welcoming environment
- Additional social services on-site
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit St. Anthony's Dining Room
2. No reservation or registration needed
3. Meals served during posted hours
4. All are welcome regardless of status
5. Access other services as needed
programs.address: 150 Golden Gate Ave, San Francisco, CA 94102

programs.name: Family Caregiver Alliance / Bay Area Caregiver Resource Center
programs.description: Free caregiver support groups, respite grants, and care planning
programs.fullDescription: Family Caregiver Alliance operates the Bay Area Caregiver Resource Center, providing support, education, and services to family caregivers of adults with chronic or disabling conditions.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free caregiver support groups
- Respite care grants
- Individual caregiver coaching
- Educational workshops
- Legal and financial consultations
- Care planning assistance
- Short-term counseling
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Call Family Caregiver Alliance
2. Complete intake assessment
3. Meet with care consultant
4. Develop personalized care plan
5. Access respite grants and services
programs.address: 785 Market St, Suite 750, San Francisco, CA 94103

programs.name: In-Home Supportive Services (IHSS)
programs.description: Paid caregiving hours for family members caring for elderly or disabled loved ones
programs.fullDescription: In-Home Supportive Services (IHSS) is California's program that pays family members or others to provide in-home care for aged, blind, or disabled individuals who qualify for Medi-Cal.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Paid caregiving by family members
- Personal care assistance
- Housekeeping and meal preparation
- Medical accompaniment
- Protective supervision
- Respite for family caregivers
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Apply through county social services
2. Must be on Medi-Cal
3. Home assessment conducted
4. Care hours determined by needs
5. Choose caregiver (can be family member)
6. Caregiver receives hourly payment

programs.name: Beyond Emancipation
programs.description: Housing, education, employment, and life skills support for foster youth ages 16-24
programs.fullDescription: Beyond Emancipation helps current and former foster youth in Alameda County transition to successful adulthood through housing, education, employment, and wellness support.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Housing assistance and placement
- Education support and tutoring
- Employment training and job placement
- Life skills development
- Mental health services
- Financial coaching
- Ongoing case management
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Contact Beyond Emancipation
2. Must be current or former foster youth ages 16-24
3. Must have connection to Alameda County
4. Complete intake assessment
5. Develop personalized success plan
6. Access comprehensive services

programs.name: First Place for Youth
programs.description: Transitional housing and comprehensive support for foster youth ages 18-24
programs.fullDescription: First Place for Youth helps foster youth ages 18-24 build the skills they need to successfully transition to adulthood through housing, education, and employment programs.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Transitional housing placement
- Education coaching and support
- Employment training and placement
- Life skills workshops
- Financial literacy education
- Mental health resources
- Long-term case management
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Contact First Place for Youth
2. Must be current or former foster youth ages 18-24
3. Complete application and interview
4. Participate in intake assessment
5. Access housing and comprehensive services

programs.name: Chafee Grant for Foster Youth
programs.description: Up to $5,000/year for college or vocational training for foster youth through age 26
programs.fullDescription: The Chafee Grant provides up to $5,000 per year for current and former foster youth to pay for career and technical training or college expenses.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Up to $5,000 per academic year
- Covers tuition, fees, books, supplies
- Can cover living expenses
- Available through age 26
- For vocational training or college
- Does not have to be repaid
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be current or former foster youth
2. Must be age 16-26
3. Complete FAFSA or CA Dream Act application
4. Check box for foster youth status
5. Enroll in eligible school or training program
6. Grant automatically considered

programs.name: San Francisco CASA
programs.description: Free trained volunteer advocates for children and youth in foster care
programs.fullDescription: San Francisco Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA) trains volunteers to advocate for children and youth in the foster care system, ensuring their voices are heard in court.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Trained volunteer advocates for foster youth
- Court advocacy and monitoring
- Educational advocacy
- Connection to services and resources
- Consistent supportive adult relationship
- Voice for child's best interests
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Foster youth referred by court or social worker
2. CASA volunteer assigned to case
3. Advocate meets regularly with child
4. Advocate reports to court
5. Support continues through case
programs.address: 870 Market St, Suite 1065, San Francisco, CA 94102

programs.name: Five Keys Schools and Programs
programs.description: Free high school diploma, GED prep, and career training for justice-involved individuals
programs.fullDescription: Five Keys provides education and workforce development for justice-involved individuals, offering high school diplomas, career training, and reentry support in the Bay Area.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free high school diploma programs
- GED preparation
- Career technical education
- Job placement assistance
- Workforce readiness training
- Wraparound support services
- Programs in jails and community
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Contact Five Keys enrollment
2. Complete intake assessment
3. Enroll in education or training program
4. Attend classes (in-person or hybrid)
5. Receive supportive services
6. Graduate and access job placement
programs.address: 70 Oak Grove St, San Francisco, CA 94107

programs.name: Project Rebound
programs.description: College enrollment support and peer mentorship for formerly incarcerated students at CSU
programs.fullDescription: Project Rebound helps formerly incarcerated individuals earn college degrees at California State University campuses, providing support services and a community of peers.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- CSU admission support
- Financial aid navigation
- Academic advising and tutoring
- Peer mentorship from formerly incarcerated students
- Career development
- Community and belonging
- Available at multiple CSU campuses
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Contact Project Rebound at your desired CSU
2. Complete intake and assessment
3. Receive application support
4. Enroll at CSU campus
5. Access ongoing support services
6. Join peer community

programs.name: Anti-Recidivism Coalition (ARC)
programs.description: Comprehensive reentry support including housing, employment, and education assistance
programs.fullDescription: The Anti-Recidivism Coalition provides reentry support, advocacy, and community for formerly and currently incarcerated people in California.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Reentry support and case management
- Housing assistance
- Employment support and job training
- Education navigation
- Policy advocacy
- Community and peer support
- Leadership development
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Contact ARC intake line
2. Must be currently or formerly incarcerated
3. Complete intake assessment
4. Meet with case manager
5. Develop reentry plan
6. Access services and join community

programs.name: Centerforce Reentry Services
programs.description: Reentry planning, family support, and connections to housing and employment
programs.fullDescription: Centerforce provides reentry services and family support for incarcerated individuals and their families, helping maintain connections and prepare for successful reintegration.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Reentry planning and case management
- Family visiting programs
- Children's services and support
- Housing assistance
- Employment readiness
- Connection to community resources
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Contact Centerforce for intake
2. Currently or formerly incarcerated individuals welcome
3. Family members also eligible
4. Complete assessment
5. Access services and support

programs.name: ACT Fee Waivers
programs.description: Receive two free ACT tests (including optional science/writing); free access to official ACT Self-Paced Course (Kaplan); send scores to up to 20 colleges; can request college application fee waivers
programs.fullDescription: The ACT offers fee waivers for students from low-income families, removing financial barriers to college entrance testing.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Two free ACT tests (with or without writing)
- Free access to official ACT Self-Paced Course (Kaplan prep)
- Send scores to up to 20 colleges for free
- Ability to request college application fee waivers
- Waived fees for late registration, standby testing, and test date changes
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be in 11th or 12th grade
2. Must meet income eligibility guidelines
3. Talk to your high school counselor about eligibility
4. Counselor will provide fee waiver form
5. Use fee waiver code when registering for ACT
6. Present fee waiver at test center

programs.name: AP Exam Fee Reductions
programs.description: $37 College Board fee reduction per exam (schools forgo $9 rebate); final cost typically $53-62 per exam (down from $99); some CA districts provide additional funding bringing cost to $0
programs.fullDescription: The College Board offers significant fee reductions on AP (Advanced Placement) exams for students with demonstrated financial need.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- $37 College Board fee reduction per AP exam
- Schools forgo $9 rebate, adding to the reduction
- Final cost typically $53-62 per exam (down from $99)
- Some California districts provide additional funding
- Some students pay $0 for exams in participating districts
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must demonstrate financial need (qualify for free/reduced lunch, etc.)
2. Talk to your AP teacher or school counselor
3. School will verify eligibility
4. Fee reduction automatically applied at registration
5. Pay reduced fee by deadline

programs.name: California College Promise Grant (CCPG)
programs.description: Waives enrollment fees ($46/unit) at all California Community Colleges for entire academic year
programs.fullDescription: The California College Promise Grant (formerly BOG Fee Waiver) waives enrollment fees at all 116 California Community Colleges for eligible students.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Waiver of enrollment fees ($46 per unit)
- Covers entire academic year
- Valid at all California Community Colleges
- May qualify for additional financial aid
- No limit on number of units covered
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Complete the FAFSA or California Dream Act Application
2. Apply through CCCApply when enrolling in a community college
3. Qualify based on income, receiving public benefits (CalFresh, TANF, etc.), or other criteria
4. Grant automatically applied to your enrollment fees
5. Renew each academic year

programs.name: Common App Fee Waiver
programs.description: Waived application fees at participating colleges through Common App
programs.fullDescription: The Common Application offers fee waivers that eliminate college application fees at over 900 participating colleges for students with financial need.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Waived application fees at participating colleges
- Valid at over 900 Common App member schools
- No limit on number of colleges
- Covers the full application fee (typically $50-90)
- Accepted at most selective colleges and universities
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Create a Common App account
2. Complete the Profile section
3. Answer the fee waiver questions in the Profile
4. If eligible, fee waiver automatically applied
5. Can also obtain fee waiver through school counselor
6. Fee waiver travels with you to all Common App colleges

programs.name: SAT Fee Waivers
programs.description: Receive two free SAT tests; unlimited score reports; waived college app fees via participating colleges; free CSS Profile; waived regional, late, and cancellation fees
programs.fullDescription: The College Board offers SAT fee waivers for low-income 11th and 12th grade students, covering test fees and providing additional benefits.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Two free SAT tests (with or without Essay)
- Unlimited score reports to colleges
- Waived college application fees at many participating schools
- Free CSS Profile for financial aid applications
- Waived fees for late registration, standby testing, and changes
- Access to Khan Academy Official SAT Practice (free for all)
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be in 11th or 12th grade
2. Must meet income eligibility guidelines (similar to free/reduced lunch)
3. Request fee waiver from your school counselor
4. Counselor provides fee waiver card/code
5. Use when registering for SAT online
6. Present at test center if requested

programs.name: A Greener Source
programs.description: Zero-cost office furniture donations including desks, chairs, filing cabinets, and other office furnishings; request furniture through website; schedule pickup or delivery
programs.fullDescription: A Greener Source is a nonprofit that diverts office furniture from landfills by donating it to other nonprofits, helping organizations furnish their spaces sustainably and at no cost.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free office desks and workstations
- Chairs (office, conference, guest)
- Filing cabinets and storage
- Conference tables
- Cubicle systems and panels
- Other office furnishings as available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit agreenersource.com and create an account
2. Register your nonprofit organization
3. Browse available furniture inventory online
4. Request items through the website
5. Schedule pickup or arrange delivery (fees may apply for delivery)

programs.name: Alameda County Property & Salvage Donations
programs.description: Donated surplus county property including office furniture, equipment, and supplies provided to eligible nonprofit organizations as in-kind donations
programs.fullDescription: Alameda County's General Services Agency donates surplus county property to eligible nonprofit organizations, providing free equipment and supplies that would otherwise be disposed of.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Surplus office furniture (desks, chairs, tables)
- Office equipment and electronics
- General supplies
- Availability varies based on county surplus
- Items provided as in-kind donations
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit in Alameda County
2. Contact the Alameda County Property & Salvage division
3. Complete donation request paperwork
4. Browse available surplus items
5. Arrange pickup of approved items

programs.name: Building Resources
programs.description: Salvaged and reusable building materials including construction supplies, fixtures, and landscaping materials available at reduced cost; some materials available for nonprofit projects
programs.fullDescription: Building Resources is a nonprofit reuse center in San Francisco that sells salvaged and donated building materials at affordable prices, with special programs for nonprofits.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Salvaged lumber and wood products
- Doors, windows, and hardware
- Plumbing and electrical fixtures
- Kitchen and bathroom cabinets
- Landscaping materials
- Paint and finishing supplies
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit the Building Resources warehouse
2. Browse available materials
3. Pay reduced prices (typically 50-90% off retail)
4. Nonprofits may qualify for additional discounts or donations
5. Transport materials yourself or arrange delivery

programs.name: California Federal Surplus Property Program
programs.description: Access to donated federal surplus property including furniture, equipment, vehicles, and technology through the State of California for eligible nonprofit organizations
programs.fullDescription: The California State Agency for Surplus Property administers federal surplus property, making it available to eligible nonprofits at a fraction of original cost.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Federal surplus furniture and office equipment
- Vehicles (cars, trucks, vans)
- Technology and electronics
- Tools and machinery
- Medical equipment
- Items at 0-15% of original acquisition cost
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Apply to become a Federal Donee through the California DGS
2. Complete application with proof of 501(c)(3) status
3. Pay annual enrollment fee
4. Once approved, browse available federal surplus
5. Request items and pay nominal service charges
6. Arrange pickup or delivery

programs.name: City of San Jos Surplus Property Donation Program
programs.description: Surplus property (valued at $1,500 or less) available to eligible nonprofits, including equipment, furnishings, and other items
programs.fullDescription: The City of San Jos donates surplus property valued at $1,500 or less to eligible nonprofit organizations, helping local groups access needed equipment and supplies.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Surplus office furniture
- Equipment and electronics
- Supplies and materials
- Items valued at $1,500 or less
- Availability varies based on city surplus
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit
2. Contact the City of San Jos surplus property office
3. Submit donation request
4. Browse available items when notified
5. Arrange pickup of approved donations

programs.name: Santa Clara County Surplus Property Donation Program
programs.description: Donated surplus county property including office furniture, equipment, and supplies available to eligible nonprofit organizations upon request and approval
programs.fullDescription: Santa Clara County donates surplus property to eligible nonprofit organizations, providing free office furniture, equipment, and supplies.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Surplus office furniture
- Office equipment
- General supplies
- Technology items (when available)
- Items provided free of charge
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit in Santa Clara County
2. Submit a donation request through the county website
3. Provide proof of nonprofit status
4. Wait for approval and notification of available items
5. Arrange pickup within specified timeframe

programs.name: Santa Clara County Library District Surplus Property Donations
programs.description: Donated surplus library property including furniture, shelving, and equipment for eligible nonprofit organizations located within Santa Clara County
programs.fullDescription: The Santa Clara County Library District donates surplus library property to nonprofit organizations located within the county.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Library shelving and display units
- Furniture (tables, chairs, desks)
- Library equipment
- Technology items (when available)
- Other surplus library property
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit in Santa Clara County
2. Apply through the library district website
3. Describe your organization and intended use
4. Wait for notification of available surplus
5. Arrange pickup of approved items

programs.name: San Francisco Virtual Warehouse
programs.description: Free surplus office furniture, supplies, and equipment from the City and County of San Francisco for nonprofits and public schools
programs.fullDescription: The San Francisco Virtual Warehouse is a city program that provides free surplus office furniture, supplies, and equipment to nonprofits and public schools.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Office furniture (desks, chairs, tables)
- Office supplies
- Electronics and technology
- Filing and storage equipment
- Miscellaneous surplus items
- All items free of charge
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a registered nonprofit or public school
2. Complete enrollment at SF Environment website
3. Create an account to access the virtual warehouse
4. Browse and request available items online
5. Schedule pickup at designated location

programs.name: SCRAP (Scroungers' Center for Re-usable Art Parts)
programs.description: Low-cost and donated arts, crafts, and educational materials including fabric, paper goods, sewing supplies, and classroom resources
programs.fullDescription: SCRAP is a creative reuse nonprofit that collects donated art and craft supplies and makes them available to teachers, artists, and nonprofits at very low cost.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Fabric and textiles
- Paper and cardboard products
- Craft and sewing supplies
- Art materials (paint, brushes, etc.)
- Classroom resources
- Unique and unusual materials
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit SCRAP's retail store in San Francisco
2. Browse available materials
3. Pay by the bag or by weight (very affordable)
4. Teachers and nonprofits may qualify for additional discounts
5. Membership programs available for frequent users

programs.name: San Mateo County Surplus Property Program
programs.description: Free surplus office furniture, supplies, and equipment for San Mateo County-based nonprofits and public schools
programs.fullDescription: San Mateo County provides free surplus office furniture, supplies, and equipment to San Mateo County-based nonprofits and public schools.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Office furniture (desks, chairs, tables)
- Office supplies
- Equipment and electronics
- Filing and storage solutions
- All items free of charge
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a nonprofit or public school in San Mateo County
2. Request an invitation through the online form
3. Complete registration once invited
4. Browse available items
5. Request items and schedule pickup

programs.name: CalABLE
programs.description: California's 529A ABLE savings account program to help people with qualifying disabilities build financial security without risking public benefits.
programs.fullDescription: CalABLE is California's tax-advantaged savings program for people with disabilities, allowing them to save money without affecting eligibility for public benefits like SSI and Medi-Cal.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Tax-advantaged savings account (529A ABLE account)
- Save up to $18,000 per year (2024 limit)
- Account balances up to $100,000 don't affect SSI eligibility
- Funds can be used for qualified disability expenses
- Multiple investment options available
- No California state income tax on earnings
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must have qualifying disability that began before age 26
2. Visit calable.ca.gov to open an account
3. Complete online enrollment
4. Choose investment options
5. Start saving with as little as $25
6. Manage account online

programs.name: AARP Foundation Tax-Aide
programs.description: Free tax preparation with special attention to those 50+; no age requirement; help with all income levels; available at libraries, community centers, and senior centers
programs.fullDescription: AARP Foundation Tax-Aide is the nation's largest free volunteer-run tax assistance program, providing free tax preparation with a focus on taxpayers 50 and older with low to moderate income.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free tax preparation and e-filing
- Help with federal and state returns
- Assistance with tax credits (EITC, Child Tax Credit, etc.)
- Special attention to seniors 50+
- No age requirement to use the service
- IRS-certified volunteers
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Use the AARP Tax-Aide locator to find a site near you
2. Many sites require appointments; some accept walk-ins
3. Bring all tax documents (W-2s, 1099s, ID, etc.)
4. Meet with a volunteer preparer
5. Review and sign your return
6. File electronically or by mail

programs.name: Alameda County Social Services Agency VITA
programs.description: Free tax preparation; help with EITC and CalEITC credits
programs.fullDescription: Alameda County Social Services Agency offers free tax preparation through the IRS Volunteer Income Tax Assistance (VITA) program for low to moderate income residents.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free tax preparation for income up to $64,000
- Help claiming Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC)
- CalEITC (California Earned Income Tax Credit) assistance
- IRS-certified volunteer preparers
- E-filing available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Check the Alameda County website for VITA site locations
2. Make appointment through online scheduler (opens late January)
3. Gather required documents (W-2s, 1099s, ID, Social Security cards)
4. Attend your scheduled appointment
5. File your return

programs.name: Community Gatepath (formerly CCRC) VITA
programs.description: Free tax preparation for low-income individuals and families
programs.fullDescription: Community Gatepath provides free tax preparation services for low-income individuals and families in Santa Clara County.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free tax preparation
- Help with federal and state returns
- Assistance with tax credits
- IRS-certified volunteer preparers
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Check the Community Gatepath website for current information
2. Locations and schedules vary by year
3. Gather required tax documents
4. Attend your appointment

programs.name: CSU East Bay VITA
programs.description: Free virtual tax prep via Zoom for income $84,000 or less
programs.fullDescription: CSU East Bay's accounting students provide free virtual tax preparation through the VITA program for taxpayers earning $84,000 or less.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free virtual tax preparation via Zoom
- Available for income up to $84,000
- Federal and state tax returns
- IRS-certified student preparers supervised by faculty
- Convenient online service
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit the CSU East Bay VITA website
2. Schedule an appointment online
3. Gather and scan/photograph your tax documents
4. Attend your Zoom appointment
5. Review and sign your return electronically

programs.name: IRS VITA Site Locator
programs.description: Free tax preparation for individuals and families earning $67,000 or less; help with EITC, Child Tax Credit, and other credits; available in multiple languages
programs.fullDescription: The IRS VITA (Volunteer Income Tax Assistance) program offers free tax help to people who generally make $64,000 or less, persons with disabilities, and limited English speakers.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free tax preparation and e-filing
- Help with EITC, Child Tax Credit, and other credits
- Service for income generally $64,000 or less
- Assistance in multiple languages
- IRS-certified volunteers
- Available at community centers, libraries, schools
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Use the IRS VITA locator tool to find a site
2. Check site requirements (appointment vs. walk-in)
3. Bring required documents (ID, Social Security cards, W-2s, 1099s)
4. Meet with a volunteer preparer
5. Review, sign, and file your return

programs.name: EBALDC VITA
programs.description: Free tax preparation
programs.fullDescription: East Bay Asian Local Development Corporation (EBALDC) offers free tax preparation through the VITA program at their SparkPoint Oakland center.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free tax preparation
- Federal and state returns
- Help with tax credits (EITC, CalEITC)
- IRS-certified preparers
- Multilingual assistance available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Email sparkpoint@ebaldc.org for information
2. Check website for current year schedule
3. Make an appointment when available
4. Bring required tax documents
5. Complete your tax filing

programs.name: Samaritan House VITA
programs.description: Free tax preparation with drop-off service
programs.fullDescription: Samaritan House provides free tax preparation services for San Mateo County residents, including a convenient drop-off service option.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free tax preparation
- Drop-off service available (no need to wait)
- Federal and state returns
- Help with tax credits
- IRS-certified volunteers
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Call for tax questions or to schedule
2. Gather all required documents
3. Drop off documents or attend in-person appointment
4. Receive call when return is ready for review
5. Sign and file your return

programs.name: SF State VITA
programs.description: Free tax preparation by accounting students
programs.fullDescription: San Francisco State University accounting students provide free tax preparation through the IRS VITA program for low to moderate income taxpayers.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free tax preparation
- Federal and California state returns
- IRS-certified student preparers
- Faculty supervision
- Service for students and community members
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Check SF State VITA website for schedule and location
2. Gather required tax documents
3. Attend during scheduled hours
4. Work with a student preparer
5. Review, sign, and file your return

programs.name: SparkPoint Fremont VITA
programs.description: Free current year and back tax preparation for low-to-moderate income families
programs.fullDescription: SparkPoint Fremont at the Fremont Family Resource Center offers free tax preparation for current year and back taxes for low to moderate income families.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free current year tax preparation (February-April)
- Free back tax preparation (year-round)
- Federal and state returns
- Help with tax credits
- IRS-certified preparers
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Contact the Fremont Family Resource Center
2. Schedule an appointment
3. Gather required tax documents
4. Attend your appointment
5. Review and sign your return

programs.name: United Way Bay Area
programs.description: Free, secure, high-quality tax help for low- and middle-income residents across the Bay Area
programs.fullDescription: United Way Bay Area partners with local organizations to provide free, high-quality tax preparation at sites throughout the Bay Area.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free tax preparation at multiple sites
- Service for low to moderate income residents
- Help with EITC and other credits
- IRS-certified volunteers
- Multiple languages available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit United Way Bay Area website
2. Find a free tax preparation site near you
3. Check if appointment is required
4. Gather required documents
5. Get your taxes filed for free

programs.name: Bay Area Entrepreneur Center
programs.description: Free business management guidance, technical assistance, networking, one-on-one consulting, and business workshops for aspiring and current entrepreneurs
programs.fullDescription: The Bay Area Entrepreneur Center at Skyline College provides free resources and support for aspiring and current entrepreneurs in San Mateo County.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free business management guidance
- One-on-one consulting with business advisors
- Business workshops and training
- Networking events
- Technical assistance for startups
- Help with business plans
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit the Bay Area Entrepreneur Center website
2. Browse available workshops and events
3. Schedule a one-on-one consultation
4. Attend workshops and networking events
5. Access ongoing support as your business grows
programs.address: 3300 College Drive, Building 1, San Bruno, CA 94066

programs.name: San Francisco SCORE
programs.description: Free and confidential business counseling plus low-cost workshops; over 50 retired and active professionals available to help
programs.fullDescription: SCORE is a nonprofit network of volunteer business mentors. San Francisco SCORE offers free mentoring and low-cost workshops to help small business owners succeed.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free one-on-one business mentoring
- Mentors are experienced business professionals
- Low-cost workshops on business topics
- Online resources and templates
- Guidance on starting, growing, or transitioning a business
- Over 50 local mentors available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit sanfrancisco.score.org
2. Browse mentor profiles and areas of expertise
3. Request a free mentoring session online
4. Meet with your mentor (in-person or virtual)
5. Continue meeting as neededit's always free

programs.name: San Mateo Small Business Development Center
programs.description: Free assistance with relief applications, cash flow management, supply chain issues, workforce capacity, and insurance coverage for small businesses
programs.fullDescription: The San Mateo SBDC provides free, confidential business advising to help small businesses start, grow, and succeed in San Mateo County.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free one-on-one business consulting
- Help with business planning and strategy
- Cash flow management assistance
- Supply chain and operations guidance
- Help with funding and loan applications
- Disaster relief application assistance
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit the San Mateo SBDC website
2. Request a free consultation
3. Complete intake form describing your business needs
4. Get matched with an advisor
5. Meet for ongoing support as needed

programs.name: NOVA Workforce Development
programs.description: Free employment and training services connecting businesses, educators, and job seekers in Silicon Valley
programs.fullDescription: NOVA Workforce connects job seekers with employment opportunities and training services, and helps businesses find qualified workers in Silicon Valley.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free career counseling and job search assistance
- Skills training and certification programs
- Resume and interview preparation
- Job placement services
- Connections to employers
- Programs for youth, adults, and dislocated workers
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit the NOVA Workforce website or office
2. Complete an orientation session
3. Meet with a career counselor
4. Access training and job search services
5. Get connected to employment opportunities
programs.address: 505 W. Olive Avenue, Suite 550, Sunnyvale, CA 94086

programs.name: Small Business Finance Center (IBank)
programs.description: Disaster Relief Loan Guarantee, Jump Start Loan Program, and other financing programs for small businesses focusing on job creation in low- to moderate-income communities
programs.fullDescription: California's IBank Small Business Finance Center offers loan guarantee programs to help small businesses access capital for growth and recovery.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Disaster Relief Loan Guarantee Program
- Jump Start Loan Program (up to $10,000 for microenterprises)
- Small Business Loan Guarantee Program
- Focus on job creation in underserved communities
- Help accessing capital when traditional loans aren't available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit the IBank website to learn about programs
2. Determine which program fits your needs
3. Work with a participating lender (IBank provides the guarantee)
4. Submit loan application through the lender
5. IBank guarantee helps you get approved

programs.name: Alameda County Community Food Bank
programs.description: The Alameda County Community Food Bank is one of the largest food banks in the nation, distributing millions of pounds of food annually through a network of partner agencies and direct distribution programs.
programs.fullDescription: The Alameda County Community Food Bank is one of the largest food banks in the nation, distributing millions of pounds of food annually through a network of partner agencies and direct distribution programs.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free groceries at 350+ distribution sites
- Fresh produce, proteins, and staples
- Mobile food pantries in underserved areas
- No ID or income verification required
- Culturally appropriate foods available
- CalFresh (food stamps) application assistance
programs.howToGetIt: Use the online Food Finder tool to locate a distribution site near you. Most sites operate on a first-come, first-served basis. Some require appointments; check individual site details.

programs.name: Alameda Meals on Wheels
programs.description: Alameda Meals on Wheels delivers nutritious meals to homebound seniors and adults with disabilities in the City of Alameda, providing both nourishment and friendly check-ins.
programs.fullDescription: Alameda Meals on Wheels delivers nutritious meals to homebound seniors and adults with disabilities in the City of Alameda, providing both nourishment and friendly check-ins.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Hot lunch delivered Monday-Friday
- Frozen weekend meals
- Friendly volunteer visits and safety checks
- Suggested donation, but no one turned away
- Special diet accommodations available
programs.howToGetIt: Call to apply. You must be 60+ or have a disability and be primarily homebound. A staff member will assess eligibility and schedule deliveries.

programs.name: Bernal Heights Neighborhood Center - Brown Bag Program
programs.description: Bernal Heights Neighborhood Center provides food assistance to San Francisco residents, including a weekly Brown Bag program for seniors and a food pantry serving all community members.
programs.fullDescription: Bernal Heights Neighborhood Center provides food assistance to San Francisco residents, including a weekly Brown Bag program for seniors and a food pantry serving all community members.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Brown Bag Program: Supplemental groceries for seniors 60+ (Thursdays)
- Weekly food pantry open to all SF residents
- Fresh produce and shelf-stable items
- No income verification required
programs.howToGetIt: For the Brown Bag program, visit on Thursdays and bring proof of age (60+) and SF residency. For the general food pantry, visit during open hours. Contact the center for current schedule.

programs.name: CalFresh Online
programs.description: CalFresh (California's SNAP/food stamps program) now allows beneficiaries to purchase groceries online from select retailers, making food access more convenient for those with transportation or mobility challenges.
programs.fullDescription: CalFresh (California's SNAP/food stamps program) now allows beneficiaries to purchase groceries online from select retailers, making food access more convenient for those with transportation or mobility challenges.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Online grocery ordering with EBT card
- Available at Amazon, Walmart, Safeway, and more
- Same eligible food items as in-store
- Home delivery or store pickup options
- Delivery fees may apply (varies by retailer)
programs.howToGetIt: If you have a CalFresh EBT card, visit a participating retailer's website. Create an account, add your EBT card, and shop for eligible groceries. Check the CDSS website for the full list of participating stores.

programs.name: CalFresh Restaurant Meals Program (RMP)
programs.description: The Restaurant Meals Program allows certain CalFresh recipients to use their EBT benefits at participating restaurants, helping those who may not have access to cooking facilities or ability to prepare meals.
programs.fullDescription: The Restaurant Meals Program allows certain CalFresh recipients to use their EBT benefits at participating restaurants, helping those who may not have access to cooking facilities or ability to prepare meals.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Use CalFresh EBT to buy prepared meals
- Available at participating restaurants (fast food and sit-down)
- Hot, ready-to-eat meals
- Includes chains like Subway, Denny's, and local restaurants
- Available in most Bay Area counties
programs.howToGetIt: You must be a CalFresh recipient who is 60+, disabled, or homeless. Check if your county participates, then use the CDSS Restaurant Locator to find participating restaurants. Show your EBT card and ID when ordering.

programs.name: Food Bank of Contra Costa & Solano
programs.description: The Food Bank of Contra Costa and Solano serves two counties with free food distribution, helping fight hunger through a network of partners and direct community programs.
programs.fullDescription: The Food Bank of Contra Costa and Solano serves two counties with free food distribution, helping fight hunger through a network of partners and direct community programs.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free groceries at distribution sites
- Mobile food pantries
- Senior food programs
- Fresh produce distributions
- CalFresh enrollment assistance
- No ID or proof of income required
programs.howToGetIt: Use the online Food Locator to find a distribution site near you. Bring bags to carry food. Most sites operate weekly; check individual site schedules.

programs.name: J-Sei Meals on Wheels
programs.description: J-Sei provides culturally appropriate Japanese-style home-delivered meals to seniors in Alameda County, honoring cultural food traditions while ensuring nutrition and social connection.
programs.fullDescription: J-Sei provides culturally appropriate Japanese-style home-delivered meals to seniors in Alameda County, honoring cultural food traditions while ensuring nutrition and social connection.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Japanese-style hot meals delivered to your home
- Culturally appropriate menu
- Available for seniors 60+ who have difficulty leaving home
- Suggested donation, but never denied for inability to pay
- Friendly check-ins with each delivery
programs.howToGetIt: Call J-Sei to apply. You must be 60+ and have difficulty leaving your home to prepare or obtain food. Staff will assess eligibility and set up meal deliveries.

programs.name: Market Match
programs.description: Market Match doubles the value of CalFresh and WIC benefits at participating farmers markets, making fresh, locally grown fruits and vegetables more affordable for low-income families.
programs.fullDescription: Market Match doubles the value of CalFresh and WIC benefits at participating farmers markets, making fresh, locally grown fruits and vegetables more affordable for low-income families.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Double your CalFresh/EBT dollars (up to $10-15 match per visit)
- Bonus funds for fresh fruits and vegetables only
- Available at 250+ farmers markets statewide
- WIC participants also eligible at many markets
- Some markets offer senior bonus programs
programs.howToGetIt: Bring your CalFresh EBT card to a participating farmers market. Visit the info booth, swipe your card, and receive matching tokens or scrip to spend on fresh produce. Check the website for participating markets.

programs.name: Meals on Wheels Contra Costa
programs.description: Meals on Wheels Contra Costa delivers nutritious meals to homebound seniors and adults with disabilities, providing nutrition, independence, and social connection through daily visits.
programs.fullDescription: Meals on Wheels Contra Costa delivers nutritious meals to homebound seniors and adults with disabilities, providing nutrition, independence, and social connection through daily visits.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Hot meal delivered Monday-Friday
- Frozen weekend meals available
- Special diets accommodated (diabetic, low-sodium, etc.)
- Friendly safety check with each delivery
- Suggested donation, but no one turned away for inability to pay
programs.howToGetIt: Call to apply. You must be 60+ or have a qualifying disability and be primarily homebound. Staff will assess your needs and schedule meal deliveries.

programs.name: Meals on Wheels Diablo Region
programs.description: Meals on Wheels Diablo Region serves the eastern Contra Costa County area, delivering meals and providing vital social connections to homebound seniors and adults with disabilities.
programs.fullDescription: Meals on Wheels Diablo Region serves the eastern Contra Costa County area, delivering meals and providing vital social connections to homebound seniors and adults with disabilities.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Home-delivered meals
- Hot and frozen meal options
- Nutrition designed for seniors
- Wellness checks with each delivery
- Volunteer companionship visits
programs.howToGetIt: Call to request services. A staff member will assess your eligibility and needs. Services available to homebound seniors 60+ and adults with disabilities.

programs.name: Meals on Wheels San Francisco
programs.description: Meals on Wheels San Francisco delivers nutritious meals to homebound seniors and adults with disabilities throughout San Francisco, ensuring no one goes hungry due to age, illness, or isolation.
programs.fullDescription: Meals on Wheels San Francisco delivers nutritious meals to homebound seniors and adults with disabilities throughout San Francisco, ensuring no one goes hungry due to age, illness, or isolation.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Hot lunch delivered Monday-Friday
- Weekend meal options
- Culturally diverse menu options
- Special diets accommodated
- Friendly volunteer check-ins
- No one turned away for inability to pay
programs.howToGetIt: Call or apply online. You must be 60+ or have a disability and be primarily homebound. Staff will assess your needs and arrange meal delivery schedule.

programs.name: Meals on Wheels San Mateo County (Peninsula Volunteers)
programs.description: Peninsula Volunteers operates Meals on Wheels in San Mateo County, delivering nutritious meals to homebound adults 60+ while providing vital social connection and wellness checks.
programs.fullDescription: Peninsula Volunteers operates Meals on Wheels in San Mateo County, delivering nutritious meals to homebound adults 60+ while providing vital social connection and wellness checks.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Hot meal delivered Monday-Friday
- Frozen weekend meals available
- Suggested donation of $5.25/meal, but never denied
- Special diet accommodations
- Friendly safety check with each delivery
- Pet food available for clients with pets
programs.howToGetIt: Call to apply. You must be 60+ and primarily homebound due to age, illness, or disability. A staff member will assess eligibility and schedule deliveries.

programs.name: Project Open Hand
programs.description: Project Open Hand provides medically tailored meals and groceries to people living with serious illnesses, as well as nutritious meals to seniors. Since 1985, they've served millions of meals with love.
programs.fullDescription: Project Open Hand provides medically tailored meals and groceries to people living with serious illnesses, as well as nutritious meals to seniors. Since 1985, they've served millions of meals with love.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Medically tailored meals for people with critical illnesses
- Nutrition counseling from registered dietitians
- Home delivery available
- Congregate meal programs for seniors
- Grocery bags and wellness checks
- Services available regardless of income
programs.howToGetIt: Call or apply online. Programs available for people with HIV/AIDS, cancer, diabetes, kidney disease, and other serious illnesses. Senior congregate meals available at community sites. Referrals from healthcare providers welcome.

programs.name: Rainbow Grocery
programs.description: Rainbow Grocery is a worker-owned cooperative grocery store in San Francisco offering natural and organic foods, with discounts for seniors and EBT cardholders.
programs.fullDescription: Rainbow Grocery is a worker-owned cooperative grocery store in San Francisco offering natural and organic foods, with discounts for seniors and EBT cardholders.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- 10% discount for shoppers 60+
- 10% discount for EBT cardholders
- Natural, organic, and local foods
- Bulk foods to save money
- Vegan and specialty diet options
- Discounts apply to all purchases
programs.howToGetIt: Show your EBT card or proof of age (60+) at checkout to receive 10% off your purchase. Discounts cannot be combined. Open daily.

programs.name: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley
programs.description: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley is one of the largest food banks in the nation, providing food to nearly half a million people each month through a network of 900+ partners and direct distribution sites.
programs.fullDescription: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley is one of the largest food banks in the nation, providing food to nearly half a million people each month through a network of 900+ partners and direct distribution sites.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free groceries at 900+ distribution sites
- Fresh produce, proteins, dairy, and staples
- Mobile food pantries
- Home delivery for homebound individuals
- No income verification required
- CalFresh enrollment assistance
programs.howToGetIt: Use the online Food Locator tool or call the Food Connection hotline. Find a site near you, check the schedule, and bring bags to carry food. Most sites require no ID or paperwork.

programs.name: SF-Marin Food Bank
programs.description: The SF-Marin Food Bank provides food to 1 in 4 San Francisco and Marin County residents, operating the largest food pantry network in the region with free groceries and nutrition programs.
programs.fullDescription: The SF-Marin Food Bank provides food to 1 in 4 San Francisco and Marin County residents, operating the largest food pantry network in the region with free groceries and nutrition programs.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free groceries at 275+ pantry sites
- Home delivery for homebound seniors and people with disabilities
- Supplemental food for seniors 60+ at senior centers
- Fresh produce, proteins, and staples
- CalFresh application assistance
- No income verification or ID required
programs.howToGetIt: Use the online Food Locator or call the food bank. Find a pantry near you and check their schedule. Bring your own bags. For home delivery, call to assess eligibility.

programs.name: SOS Meals on Wheels
programs.description: SOS Meals on Wheels serves the Oakland and surrounding areas with daily home-delivered meals for homebound seniors, providing nutrition and social connection for over 50 years.
programs.fullDescription: SOS Meals on Wheels serves the Oakland and surrounding areas with daily home-delivered meals for homebound seniors, providing nutrition and social connection for over 50 years.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Hot meal delivered daily, Monday-Friday
- Frozen weekend meals
- Special diets available (diabetic, low-sodium, pureed)
- Friendly volunteer check-ins
- Suggested donation, but no one turned away
programs.howToGetIt: Call to apply. You must be 60+ and homebound due to illness, disability, or frailty. Staff will assess your needs and schedule meal deliveries.

programs.name: Sourcewise Meals on Wheels
programs.description: Sourcewise provides Meals on Wheels throughout Santa Clara County, delivering two nutritious meals daily to homebound seniors and adults with disabilities.
programs.fullDescription: Sourcewise provides Meals on Wheels throughout Santa Clara County, delivering two nutritious meals daily to homebound seniors and adults with disabilities.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Two meals per day delivered to your home
- Meals meet 2/3 of daily nutritional requirements
- Hot and cold meal options
- Special diets accommodated
- Suggested contribution of $3/day, but never denied
- Safety check with each delivery
programs.howToGetIt: Call Sourcewise to apply. You must be 60+ or have a disability and be homebound. Staff will assess eligibility and arrange meal delivery.

programs.name: Spectrum Community Services Meals on Wheels
programs.description: Spectrum Community Services delivers Meals on Wheels to seniors in central and east Contra Costa County, helping older adults maintain independence and nutrition at home.
programs.fullDescription: Spectrum Community Services delivers Meals on Wheels to seniors in central and east Contra Costa County, helping older adults maintain independence and nutrition at home.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Home-delivered meals for seniors 60+
- Available for those unable to prepare food
- Nutrition designed for older adults
- Friendly volunteer visits
- Sliding scale donations accepted
programs.howToGetIt: Call Spectrum Community Services to apply. You must be 60+ and unable to prepare your own meals due to health or mobility limitations.

programs.name: St. Anthony's Dining Room
programs.description: St. Anthony's Dining Room has served San Francisco's Tenderloin neighborhood since 1950, providing free hot meals daily with dignity and respect to all who are hungry, no questions asked.
programs.fullDescription: St. Anthony's Dining Room has served San Francisco's Tenderloin neighborhood since 1950, providing free hot meals daily with dignity and respect to all who are hungry, no questions asked.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free hot meals served daily
- Dine-in or to-go options
- No ID, referral, or questions asked
- Breakfast and lunch available
- Clean, safe, welcoming environment
- Additional social services available on-site
programs.howToGetIt: Simply show up during meal service hours. No paperwork, ID, or appointment needed. All are welcome. Check website for current hours.
programs.address: 150 Golden Gate Avenue, San Francisco, CA 94102

programs.name: Universal School Meals
programs.description: California became the first state to offer universal free school meals to all public school students regardless of family income, ensuring every child has access to nutritious breakfast and lunch.
programs.fullDescription: California became the first state to offer universal free school meals to all public school students regardless of family income, ensuring every child has access to nutritious breakfast and lunch.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free breakfast for all TK-12 students
- Free lunch for all TK-12 students
- Available at all California public schools
- No income verification or application required
- Nutritious, balanced meals meeting USDA standards
- Available every school day
programs.howToGetIt: Your child automatically qualifies. Simply have them request meals at school. No forms or applications needed. Contact your school's food services if you have questions about meal times or menus.

programs.name: WIC  Women, Infants & Children
programs.description: WIC is California's nutrition program for pregnant and postpartum women, infants, and children under 5, providing healthy food, nutrition education, breastfeeding support, and healthcare referrals.
programs.fullDescription: WIC is California's nutrition program for pregnant and postpartum women, infants, and children under 5, providing healthy food, nutrition education, breastfeeding support, and healthcare referrals.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Monthly benefits for healthy foods (fruits, vegetables, whole grains, milk, eggs)
- Infant formula and baby food
- WIC card accepted at most grocery stores
- Nutrition counseling
- Breastfeeding support and free breast pumps
- Farmers market benefits
- Referrals to healthcare and social services
programs.howToGetIt: Apply online or contact your local WIC office. You'll need proof of income (up to 185% of poverty level), residency, and identity. Pregnant women, new mothers, infants, and children under 5 may qualify.

programs.name: YMCA Food Pantries
programs.description: The YMCA of San Francisco operates food pantries throughout the Bay Area, providing free groceries to families and individuals facing food insecurity.
programs.fullDescription: The YMCA of San Francisco operates food pantries throughout the Bay Area, providing free groceries to families and individuals facing food insecurity.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free groceries at 17 Bay Area locations
- Serves 6,900+ people weekly
- Fresh produce, proteins, and staples
- Diapers and essentials at some locations
- No income verification required
- Family-friendly environment
programs.howToGetIt: Visit any YMCA food pantry location during open hours. Check the website for locations, days, and times. No registration required at most sites.

programs.name: Ecumenical Hunger Program
programs.description: The Ecumenical Hunger Program serves East Palo Alto and surrounding communities with nutritionally balanced food boxes, helping families stretch their food budgets.
programs.fullDescription: The Ecumenical Hunger Program serves East Palo Alto and surrounding communities with nutritionally balanced food boxes, helping families stretch their food budgets.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Nutritionally balanced food boxes
- Fresh produce when available
- Available for families and individuals
- Appointment required
- Serving East Palo Alto and neighboring communities
- Additional services including clothing and furniture
programs.howToGetIt: Call to schedule an appointment. First-time clients should bring proof of address. Food distribution is available on scheduled days.
programs.address: 2411 Pulgas Avenue, East Palo Alto, CA 94303

programs.name: JFCS Food Pantry
programs.description: Jewish Family and Children's Services (JFCS) operates a food pantry providing high-protein, nutritious food to seniors, disabled adults, and low-income families in Santa Clara County.
programs.fullDescription: Jewish Family and Children's Services (JFCS) operates a food pantry providing high-protein, nutritious food to seniors, disabled adults, and low-income families in Santa Clara County.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- High-protein nutritious food boxes
- Available for seniors on fixed income
- Serves disabled adults and low-income families
- Kosher options available
- Culturally sensitive food choices
programs.howToGetIt: Contact JFCS to learn about eligibility and how to access the food pantry. Services available to Santa Clara County residents.

programs.name: Got Groceries Program
programs.description: Peninsula Volunteers' Got Groceries program provides weekly bags of free groceries to individuals and families facing food insecurity in San Mateo County.
programs.fullDescription: Peninsula Volunteers' Got Groceries program provides weekly bags of free groceries to individuals and families facing food insecurity in San Mateo County.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Full bag of groceries weekly
- Fresh produce, proteins, and breads
- Available to individuals and families
- Distribution every Wednesday
- No income verification required
programs.howToGetIt: Visit a Got Groceries distribution site on Wednesdays. Check the Peninsula Volunteers website for locations and times. No registration required.

programs.name: 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline
programs.description: The 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline is a national network of local crisis centers providing free, confidential emotional support 24/7 to people in suicidal crisis or emotional distress.
programs.fullDescription: The 988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline is a national network of local crisis centers providing free, confidential emotional support 24/7 to people in suicidal crisis or emotional distress.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- 24/7 phone, text, and chat support
- Trained crisis counselors available in English and Spanish
- Specialized support for veterans (press 1)
- LGBTQ+ specific support available
- Deaf/hard of hearing support via TTY
programs.howToGetIt: Call or text 988 from any phone, anytime. You can also chat online at 988lifeline.org. No appointment or insurance needed.

programs.name: Crisis Text Line
programs.description: Crisis Text Line is a free, 24/7 text-based mental health support service connecting people in crisis with trained volunteer counselors through text messages.
programs.fullDescription: Crisis Text Line is a free, 24/7 text-based mental health support service connecting people in crisis with trained volunteer counselors through text messages.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free 24/7 crisis support via text
- Trained volunteer crisis counselors
- Confidential conversations
- Support for anxiety, depression, suicidal thoughts, abuse, and more
- Available in English and Spanish
programs.howToGetIt: Text HOME to 741741 from anywhere in the US. A trained crisis counselor will respond within minutes. Free on all carriers.

programs.name: Denti-Cal
programs.description: Denti-Cal is California's Medicaid dental program, providing comprehensive dental care to Medi-Cal beneficiaries at no cost, helping ensure oral health for low-income individuals and families.
programs.fullDescription: Denti-Cal is California's Medicaid dental program, providing comprehensive dental care to Medi-Cal beneficiaries at no cost, helping ensure oral health for low-income individuals and families.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Preventive care (cleanings, exams, x-rays)
- Restorative services (fillings, crowns)
- Extractions and oral surgery
- Dentures and partials
- Emergency dental services
- Orthodontics for children under 21 (when medically necessary)
programs.howToGetIt: If you have Medi-Cal, you automatically have Denti-Cal. Find a Denti-Cal provider using the online provider search or call the Denti-Cal hotline at 1-800-322-6384.

programs.name: EyeCare America
programs.description: EyeCare America is a public service program of the American Academy of Ophthalmology providing eye care to seniors through volunteer ophthalmologists who donate their services.
programs.fullDescription: EyeCare America is a public service program of the American Academy of Ophthalmology providing eye care to seniors through volunteer ophthalmologists who donate their services.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free comprehensive eye exam
- Up to one year of follow-up care
- Diagnosis and treatment for eye diseases
- Glaucoma and diabetic eye disease screening
- No out-of-pocket costs for eligible patients
programs.howToGetIt: You must be 65 or older, a US citizen or legal resident, not enrolled in an HMO or VA, and not seen an ophthalmologist in 3+ years. Check eligibility and find a volunteer doctor online or call 1-877-887-6327.

programs.name: Medi-Cal (Medicaid)
programs.description: Medi-Cal is California's Medicaid program, providing free or low-cost health coverage to millions of Californians including low-income adults, families, seniors, pregnant women, and people with disabilities.
programs.fullDescription: Medi-Cal is California's Medicaid program, providing free or low-cost health coverage to millions of Californians including low-income adults, families, seniors, pregnant women, and people with disabilities.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Doctor and hospital visits
- Prescription medications
- Preventive care and screenings
- Mental health services
- Dental care (Denti-Cal)
- Vision care
- Substance use treatment
- Long-term care services
programs.howToGetIt: Apply online at CoveredCA.com, through your county human services office, or by phone at 1-800-300-1506. You'll need proof of income, residency, and identity. Many people can enroll year-round.

programs.name: NeedyMeds
programs.description: NeedyMeds is a nonprofit providing a comprehensive database of patient assistance programs, helping people find affordable medications and healthcare services regardless of insurance status.
programs.fullDescription: NeedyMeds is a nonprofit providing a comprehensive database of patient assistance programs, helping people find affordable medications and healthcare services regardless of insurance status.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Database of 1,500+ patient assistance programs
- Free drug discount card (up to 80% off)
- Listings of free/low-cost clinics
- Coupons and rebates for medications
- Disease-specific assistance programs
- Information on government programs
programs.howToGetIt: Visit needymeds.org and search by drug name, condition, or program type. Download the free NeedyMeds Drug Discount Card online or request one by mail. No registration required.

programs.name: Planned Parenthood
programs.description: Planned Parenthood is a trusted healthcare provider offering sexual and reproductive health services on a sliding fee scale, ensuring care is accessible regardless of insurance status or ability to pay.
programs.fullDescription: Planned Parenthood is a trusted healthcare provider offering sexual and reproductive health services on a sliding fee scale, ensuring care is accessible regardless of insurance status or ability to pay.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Birth control and contraception counseling
- STI testing and treatment
- HIV testing
- Cancer screenings (breast, cervical)
- Pregnancy testing and options counseling
- Abortion services
- Transgender hormone therapy
- General health care and wellness exams
programs.howToGetIt: Find your nearest health center online or call 1-800-230-PLAN. Walk-ins welcome at many locations, but appointments recommended. Payment based on income; many services covered by Medi-Cal and Family PACT.

programs.name: Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program
programs.description: The Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program provides comprehensive care and support services for people living with HIV who are uninsured or underinsured, filling gaps in care not covered by other sources.
programs.fullDescription: The Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program provides comprehensive care and support services for people living with HIV who are uninsured or underinsured, filling gaps in care not covered by other sources.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Primary medical care and specialist visits
- HIV medications and treatment
- Mental health services
- Substance abuse treatment
- Case management
- Transportation to appointments
- Emergency financial assistance
- Housing assistance
programs.howToGetIt: Contact your local Ryan White provider or AIDS service organization. You'll need proof of HIV diagnosis, residency, and income. Use the HIV care locator to find services near you.

programs.name: SAMHSA National Helpline
programs.description: SAMHSA's National Helpline is a free, confidential, 24/7 treatment referral and information service for individuals and families facing mental health and/or substance use disorders.
programs.fullDescription: SAMHSA's National Helpline is a free, confidential, 24/7 treatment referral and information service for individuals and families facing mental health and/or substance use disorders.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- 24/7 confidential support
- Treatment referrals in your area
- Information about mental health and substance use
- Support in English and Spanish
- Referrals to local support groups
- Information about state-funded treatment programs
- Help finding sliding-scale or free treatment
programs.howToGetIt: Call 1-800-662-4357 anytime, 24/7, 365 days a year. Specialists will connect you with local treatment facilities, support groups, and community organizations. TTY available at 1-800-487-4889.

programs.name: VA Health Benefits
programs.description: VA Health Benefits provide comprehensive healthcare services to eligible veterans through the Veterans Health Administration, the nation's largest integrated healthcare system.
programs.fullDescription: VA Health Benefits provide comprehensive healthcare services to eligible veterans through the Veterans Health Administration, the nation's largest integrated healthcare system.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Primary care and specialty care
- Mental health services and counseling
- Prescription medications
- Preventive care and screenings
- Women's health services
- Urgent and emergency care
- Telehealth appointments
- Prosthetics and medical equipment
programs.howToGetIt: Apply online at VA.gov, by phone at 1-877-222-8387, or in person at any VA medical center. You'll need your DD214 or other discharge documents. Most veterans who served on active duty are eligible.

programs.name: WIC (Women, Infants, Children)
programs.description: WIC is a nutrition program providing healthy food, nutrition education, breastfeeding support, and healthcare referrals to pregnant and postpartum women, infants, and children under 5 in California.
programs.fullDescription: WIC is a nutrition program providing healthy food, nutrition education, breastfeeding support, and healthcare referrals to pregnant and postpartum women, infants, and children under 5 in California.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Monthly benefits for nutritious foods (fruits, vegetables, whole grains, milk, eggs)
- Infant formula and baby food
- Nutrition education and counseling
- Breastfeeding support and breast pumps
- Health screenings and referrals
- Farmers' market benefits
- WIC card accepted at most grocery stores
programs.howToGetIt: Contact your local WIC office or call 1-888-942-9675. You'll need proof of income (up to 185% of poverty level), residency, and identity. Pregnant women, new mothers, infants, and children under 5 may qualify.

programs.name: Behavioral Health and Recovery Services (BHRS)
programs.description: San Mateo County Behavioral Health and Recovery Services provides mental health and substance use treatment, prevention, and recovery services to residents of all ages in San Mateo County.
programs.fullDescription: San Mateo County Behavioral Health and Recovery Services provides mental health and substance use treatment, prevention, and recovery services to residents of all ages in San Mateo County.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Mental health assessment and treatment
- Substance use disorder treatment
- Crisis intervention services
- Youth and family services
- Older adult services
- Peer support programs
- Prevention and early intervention
- Housing support for clients
programs.howToGetIt: Call the Access Call Center at 1-800-686-0101 for a free assessment and referral. Services available for Medi-Cal recipients at no cost; sliding scale available for others.

programs.name: Aging and Adult Services
programs.description: San Mateo County Aging and Adult Services provides protective services, in-home care, and nutrition programs to help older adults and people with disabilities live safely and independently.
programs.fullDescription: San Mateo County Aging and Adult Services provides protective services, in-home care, and nutrition programs to help older adults and people with disabilities live safely and independently.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Adult Protective Services (abuse prevention)
- In-Home Supportive Services (IHSS)
- Public Guardian/Conservator services
- Congregate and home-delivered meals
- Senior centers and activities
- Health insurance counseling (HICAP)
- Long-term care ombudsman
programs.howToGetIt: Call Aging and Adult Services at (650) 573-3900 for information and referrals. For abuse reports, call the 24-hour hotline at 1-800-675-8437. Services available to adults 60+ and adults with disabilities.

programs.name: San Mateo County Pregnancy, Children and Families
programs.description: San Mateo County's Family Health Services provides prenatal care, home visiting, and child health programs to support healthy pregnancies and child development for families throughout the county.
programs.fullDescription: San Mateo County's Family Health Services provides prenatal care, home visiting, and child health programs to support healthy pregnancies and child development for families throughout the county.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free home visits for pregnant women and new parents
- Black Infant Health program
- Nurse-Family Partnership
- Child health and disability prevention
- Immunization services
- School-based health centers
- Dental services for children
- Services in English, Spanish, and other languages
programs.howToGetIt: Call (650) 573-2501 for program information. Free for Medi-Cal recipients; sliding fee scale for other county residents based on income.

programs.name: CalRx OTC Naloxone Nasal Spray
programs.description: CalRx is California's initiative to make naloxone, a life-saving medication that reverses opioid overdoses, affordable and accessible to all residents without a prescription.
programs.fullDescription: CalRx is California's initiative to make naloxone, a life-saving medication that reverses opioid overdoses, affordable and accessible to all residents without a prescription.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- 4mg naloxone nasal spray (Narcan-equivalent)
- Twin pack for $19 plus shipping
- No prescription required
- Significantly below retail price ($45+)
- Simple nasal spray administration
- Shelf life of 2+ years
programs.howToGetIt: Order online at CalRx.ca.gov. Add to cart, enter shipping information, and pay by credit card. Delivered directly to your home. Training videos available on the website.

programs.name: Naloxone Distribution Project (NDP)
programs.description: California's Naloxone Distribution Project provides free naloxone and fentanyl test strips to eligible nonprofit organizations working to prevent opioid overdose deaths in their communities.
programs.fullDescription: California's Naloxone Distribution Project provides free naloxone and fentanyl test strips to eligible nonprofit organizations working to prevent opioid overdose deaths in their communities.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free naloxone nasal sprays
- Free fentanyl test strips
- Training materials and resources
- Support for community distribution
- Available to eligible nonprofits statewide
programs.howToGetIt: Organizations must apply through the California Department of Health Care Services. Eligible entities include community-based organizations, harm reduction programs, and healthcare providers serving at-risk populations.
