programs.name: AIDS Drug Assistance Program (ADAP)
programs.description: California's AIDS Drug Assistance Program provides life-saving HIV/AIDS medications and health insurance assistance to low-income Californians living with HIV who lack adequate coverage.
programs.fullDescription: California's AIDS Drug Assistance Program provides life-saving HIV/AIDS medications and health insurance assistance to low-income Californians living with HIV who lack adequate coverage.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free HIV/AIDS medications (200+ drugs covered)
- Health insurance premium assistance (OA-HIPP)
- Medicare Part D premium assistance
- Medi-Cal share of cost assistance
- Covers residents with income up to 600% FPL
- Available regardless of immigration status
programs.howToGetIt: Apply through an ADAP enrollment site (clinics, AIDS service organizations, hospitals). You'll need proof of HIV diagnosis, California residency, income, and current insurance status.

programs.name: Kick It California (Quit Smoking Helpline)
programs.description: Kick It California is the state's free quit smoking and tobacco helpline, offering personalized coaching, a mobile app, and resources to help Californians quit tobacco, vaping, and marijuana.
programs.fullDescription: Kick It California is the state's free quit smoking and tobacco helpline, offering personalized coaching, a mobile app, and resources to help Californians quit tobacco, vaping, and marijuana.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free one-on-one phone coaching
- Personalized quit plan
- Mobile app for tracking progress
- Text and email support
- Resources for quitting vaping
- Marijuana coaching (ages 13-29)
- Available in English, Spanish, Chinese, Korean, Vietnamese
- Free nicotine patches (while supplies last)
programs.howToGetIt: Call 1-800-300-8086 or visit kickitca.org to get started. Coaching is free, confidential, and available in multiple languages. You can also enroll through the mobile app.

programs.name: Black Infant Health Program
programs.description: The Black Infant Health Program is California's community-based program providing group support and education to Black women and birthing people during pregnancy and the first year of their baby's life.
programs.fullDescription: The Black Infant Health Program is California's community-based program providing group support and education to Black women and birthing people during pregnancy and the first year of their baby's life.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Weekly group sessions during pregnancy
- Postpartum support groups
- Life skills and stress management
- Health education and resources
- Social support and community building
- Connection to prenatal care
- Baby supplies and incentives
- Available in 18+ California counties
programs.howToGetIt: Contact your local Black Infant Health program through the state website. Programs are free and open to Black women and birthing people age 18+ who are pregnant or recently gave birth.

programs.name: California Home Visiting Program
programs.description: The California Home Visiting Program provides free, voluntary home visits to pregnant women and families with young children, offering parenting support, health education, and connections to community resources.
programs.fullDescription: The California Home Visiting Program provides free, voluntary home visits to pregnant women and families with young children, offering parenting support, health education, and connections to community resources.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Regular home visits by trained nurses or family specialists
- Parenting education and support
- Child development monitoring
- Breastfeeding support
- Connections to healthcare and social services
- Goal setting and life skills
- Support from pregnancy through age 5
- Services in multiple languages
programs.howToGetIt: Contact your local health department or use the state website to find programs in your area. Priority given to first-time parents, low-income families, and families with risk factors.

programs.name: Vaccines for Children (VFC) Program
programs.description: The Vaccines for Children program provides free vaccines to children 18 and under who might not otherwise be vaccinated because of inability to pay, ensuring all children have access to life-saving immunizations.
programs.fullDescription: The Vaccines for Children program provides free vaccines to children 18 and under who might not otherwise be vaccinated because of inability to pay, ensuring all children have access to life-saving immunizations.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- All recommended childhood vaccines free of charge
- Available for children 0-18 years old
- DTaP, Polio, MMR, Hepatitis, HPV, and more
- Flu vaccines
- COVID-19 vaccines
- Catch-up vaccines for older children
programs.howToGetIt: Find a VFC provider near you through the state immunization registry. Children qualify if uninsured, enrolled in Medi-Cal, underinsured, or American Indian/Alaska Native. Bring your child's immunization record.

programs.name: PrEP Assistance Program (PrEP-AP)
programs.description: California's PrEP Assistance Program makes HIV prevention medication accessible to residents who might not otherwise afford it, covering the cost of PrEP medication, doctor visits, and lab tests.
programs.fullDescription: California's PrEP Assistance Program makes HIV prevention medication accessible to residents who might not otherwise afford it, covering the cost of PrEP medication, doctor visits, and lab tests.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free PrEP medication (Truvada, Descovy, or generic)
- Coverage for doctor visits and HIV testing
- Lab work costs covered
- Available to residents with income up to 500% FPL
- PrEP-AP Immediate Access: One free month for anyone
- No immigration status requirements
- Helps uninsured and underinsured individuals
programs.howToGetIt: Enroll through an ADAP enrollment site or healthcare provider. For immediate access to one free month, contact a PrEP-AP provider. You'll need proof of California residency and income.

programs.name: Every Woman Counts
programs.description: Every Woman Counts provides free breast and cervical cancer screenings to uninsured and underinsured California women, helping detect cancer early when treatment is most effective.
programs.fullDescription: Every Woman Counts provides free breast and cervical cancer screenings to uninsured and underinsured California women, helping detect cancer early when treatment is most effective.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free mammograms
- Clinical breast exams
- Pap tests (cervical cancer screening)
- HPV tests
- Follow-up diagnostic testing if needed
- Connection to treatment through BCCTP
- Available at hundreds of providers statewide
programs.howToGetIt: Call 1-800-511-2300 to find a provider and check eligibility. You must be a California resident, age 21+, with income at or below 200% of the federal poverty level, and uninsured or underinsured for these services.

programs.name: Comprehensive Perinatal Services Program (CPSP)
programs.description: The Comprehensive Perinatal Services Program provides enhanced prenatal and postpartum care to Medi-Cal recipients, offering additional support services beyond standard obstetric care to improve birth outcomes.
programs.fullDescription: The Comprehensive Perinatal Services Program provides enhanced prenatal and postpartum care to Medi-Cal recipients, offering additional support services beyond standard obstetric care to improve birth outcomes.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Enhanced prenatal care visits
- Nutrition counseling and education
- Psychosocial assessment and support
- Health education classes
- Care coordination
- Postpartum care through 60 days after delivery
- Breastfeeding support
- Referrals to community resources
programs.howToGetIt: If you're pregnant and have Medi-Cal, ask your prenatal care provider if they're a CPSP provider. CPSP services are covered at no additional cost through Medi-Cal.

programs.name: Childhood Lead Poisoning Prevention Program
programs.description: California's Childhood Lead Poisoning Prevention Program provides screening, case management, and environmental investigation to protect children from lead exposure, which can cause learning disabilities and developmental delays.
programs.fullDescription: California's Childhood Lead Poisoning Prevention Program provides screening, case management, and environmental investigation to protect children from lead exposure, which can cause learning disabilities and developmental delays.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free blood lead testing for children
- Case management for children with elevated lead levels
- Environmental investigation of lead sources
- Home assessment and lead hazard identification
- Nutritional counseling
- Connection to developmental services
- Education for parents and caregivers
programs.howToGetIt: All children on Medi-Cal must be tested at ages 1 and 2. Contact your county health department's lead program if your child has been exposed to lead or you're concerned about lead in your home.

programs.name: MyTurn
programs.description: MyTurn is California's official vaccine scheduling and digital record system, making it easy to find vaccine appointments, access your immunization records, and stay up to date on recommended vaccines.
programs.fullDescription: MyTurn is California's official vaccine scheduling and digital record system, making it easy to find vaccine appointments, access your immunization records, and stay up to date on recommended vaccines.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- COVID-19 vaccine appointments
- Flu vaccine locations
- Mpox vaccine scheduling
- Routine vaccine appointments
- Digital vaccine record access
- Walk-in clinic locator
- Support in 250+ languages
- Mobile-friendly interface
programs.howToGetIt: Visit myturn.ca.gov to search for vaccines near you. Enter your zip code, select the vaccine you need, and book an appointment. You can also access your digital vaccine record by verifying your identity.

programs.name: Court Fee Waivers
programs.description: Filing fees waived
programs.fullDescription: California courts offer fee waivers for individuals who cannot afford to pay court filing fees, ensuring access to the justice system regardless of income.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Waiver of court filing fees
- Waiver of motion fees and jury fees
- Waiver of fees for court-appointed interpreter
- Free copies of necessary court documents
- Fee waiver for court reporter services in some cases
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Obtain Form FW-001 (Request to Waive Court Fees) from the court clerk or online
2. Complete the form with income and household information
3. You automatically qualify if you receive public benefits (Medi-Cal, CalFresh, SSI, etc.)
4. Or if household income is 125% or below Federal Poverty Level
5. Submit form to the court clerk before or with your first court filing
6. Judge will review and approve or deny within 5 court days

programs.name: Justice & Diversity Center (JDC)
programs.description: Pro bono legal services for low-income/unhoused San Francisco residents and local nonprofits that serve low-income communities
programs.fullDescription: The Justice & Diversity Center is the nonprofit arm of the Bar Association of San Francisco, providing free legal services to those who cannot afford attorneys.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free legal clinics and advice sessions
- Pro bono representation in civil matters
- Legal help for housing, family law, immigration, and more
- Corporate law assistance for nonprofits serving low-income communities
- Lawyer referral services
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit the JDC website or call to learn about available programs
2. Attend a free legal clinic in your area of need
3. Complete intake and eligibility screening
4. If eligible, receive free legal advice or representation
5. Nonprofits can apply for corporate legal assistance separately
programs.address: 301 Battery Street, 3rd Floor, San Francisco, CA 94111

programs.name: Racial Equity Project (REP)
programs.description: Pro bono legal support for Black-led nonprofit organizations through partnerships with community foundations
programs.fullDescription: The Racial Equity Project provides free legal support to Black-led nonprofit organizations in California, helping strengthen their organizational capacity and mission.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Pro bono corporate legal services for Black-led nonprofits
- Help with contracts, employment matters, and governance
- Legal review and risk assessment
- Board and compliance support
- Partnership with major law firms
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Organization must be Black-led (Black executive director or majority Black board)
2. Must be a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit
3. Apply through the JDC website
4. Describe your legal needs and organization's mission
5. If accepted, be matched with pro bono attorneys

programs.name: SF Financial Justice Project
programs.description: Helps reduce or eliminate certain city fines and fees (parking, towing, etc.) for eligible residents
programs.fullDescription: The San Francisco Financial Justice Project works to reduce the impact of fines, fees, and financial penalties on low-income residents and communities of color.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Reduction or elimination of parking tickets based on income
- Help with towing and booting fee relief
- Assistance with court fines and fees
- Information about payment plans
- Advocacy for systemic reform of punitive fees
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit sfgov.org/financialjustice to learn about available programs
2. For parking ticket relief: Apply through SFMTA's Low-Income Payment Plan
3. For towing relief: Contact the office directly
4. Provide proof of income or public benefits enrollment
5. Receive determination on fee reduction or elimination

programs.name: San Francisco Immigrant Support
programs.description: Free or low-cost immigration legal help (citizenship, green cards, DACA, etc.)
programs.fullDescription: San Francisco provides resources and support for immigrants, including connections to free and low-cost immigration legal services regardless of immigration status.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free or low-cost immigration legal consultations
- Help with citizenship and naturalization applications
- DACA renewal assistance
- Green card and visa support
- Know Your Rights information
- Referrals to trusted legal providers
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit immigrants.sfgov.org for list of legal service providers
2. Call 311 for referrals to immigration legal help
3. Attend a free immigration legal clinic
4. Complete intake and eligibility screening with provider
5. Receive legal assistance based on your needs

programs.name: USCIS I-912 Fee Waiver
programs.description: Waiver of filing fees for certain immigration forms based on income/benefits
programs.fullDescription: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) offers fee waivers for certain immigration applications for individuals who cannot afford the filing fees.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Waiver of filing fees for certain immigration forms
- Available for naturalization (N-400), green card renewal (I-90), and other forms
- Based on income, receipt of means-tested benefits, or financial hardship
- Does not affect your immigration case or chances of approval
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Download Form I-912 from uscis.gov
2. Determine your basis for fee waiver (means-tested benefit, income below 150% FPL, or hardship)
3. Gather supporting documents (benefit letters, tax returns, pay stubs)
4. Submit I-912 with your immigration application
5. USCIS will review and notify you of approval or denial
6. If denied, you must pay the fee to continue your application

programs.name: Community Legal Services in East Palo Alto
programs.description: Free legal services for low-income families including immigration, housing, workers' rights, record clearance, and consumer protection
programs.fullDescription: Community Legal Services in East Palo Alto (CLSEPA) provides free legal assistance to low-income families in San Mateo County and surrounding areas.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Immigration legal services (family petitions, DACA, citizenship)
- Housing and tenant rights assistance
- Workers' rights and wage theft claims
- Criminal record clearance (expungement)
- Consumer protection
- Community education workshops
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Call CLSEPA or visit their website to schedule an appointment
2. Complete intake and financial eligibility screening
3. Must meet income guidelines (generally 200% FPL or below)
4. Attend initial consultation with staff attorney
5. Receive ongoing representation if case is accepted
programs.address: 1861 Bay Road, East Palo Alto, CA 94303

programs.name: Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County
programs.description: Free legal help for housing, healthcare access, economic security, immigration, education, and freedom from violence and abuse
programs.fullDescription: The Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County provides free civil legal services to low-income residents, helping protect their rights and improve their lives.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Housing law (eviction defense, habitability issues)
- Healthcare access (Medi-Cal, insurance appeals)
- Economic security (public benefits, consumer issues)
- Immigration assistance
- Education rights
- Protection from domestic violence and abuse
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Call the intake line or apply online
2. Complete eligibility screening (income must be 200% FPL or below)
3. Describe your legal issue
4. If eligible, schedule appointment with attorney
5. Receive legal advice, brief services, or full representation
programs.address: 330 Twin Dolphin Drive, Suite 123, Redwood City, CA 94065

programs.name: Project Sentinel Fair Housing
programs.description: Free fair housing education, counseling, and housing discrimination complaint investigation and advocacy
programs.fullDescription: Project Sentinel is a nonprofit fair housing agency that works to eliminate housing discrimination and ensure equal housing opportunity for all Bay Area residents.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free fair housing education and counseling
- Investigation of housing discrimination complaints
- Legal advocacy and representation in fair housing cases
- Landlord-tenant mediation services
- First-time homebuyer education
- Foreclosure prevention counseling
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Call or visit the Project Sentinel website
2. Describe your housing situation or discrimination concern
3. Staff will assess your case and explain your rights
4. If discrimination is found, they can investigate and advocate on your behalf
5. Services are free for all, regardless of income
programs.address: 1490 El Camino Real, Santa Clara, CA 95050

programs.name: Berkeley Tool Lending Library
programs.description: Borrow tools (power tools, lawn care equipment, etc.) free with library card
programs.fullDescription: The Berkeley Public Library operates the only tool lending library in Northern California, allowing library cardholders to borrow tools for free.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Power tools (drills, saws, sanders)
- Lawn and garden equipment
- Hand tools (hammers, wrenches, screwdrivers)
- Specialty tools (tile cutters, pipe wrenches)
- Automotive tools
- Free to borrow with library card
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Get a Berkeley Public Library card (free for residents)
2. Visit the Tool Lending Library at the South Branch
3. Browse available tools in person
4. Check out tools with your library card
5. Return within the borrowing period (typically 3-7 days)

programs.name: California State Parks Library Pass
programs.description: Free vehicle day-use entry to 200+ participating state parks (1 vehicle up to 9 people or 1 motorcycle). Not valid for camping, museums within parks, or special events.
programs.fullDescription: California State Library's Parks Pass program allows library patrons to check out day-use passes for free entry to over 200 state parks.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free vehicle day-use entry to 200+ state parks
- Covers 1 vehicle with up to 9 people or 1 motorcycle
- Valid at participating state parks statewide
- Does not cover camping or special events
- Does not cover museums within parks
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Have a valid library card from a participating library
2. Check your library's website for pass availability
3. Reserve or check out a parks pass
4. Bring the pass and your library card to the park
5. Return pass by the due date

programs.name: Calm Meditation App
programs.description: Free Calm access for qualifying library patrons with guided meditations, courses, stories, music, and stress management tools via web and mobile app
programs.fullDescription: San Mateo County Library provides free access to the Calm app, offering guided meditations, sleep stories, and stress management tools.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Full access to Calm premium features
- Guided meditations
- Sleep stories
- Relaxing music
- Breathing exercises
- Stress management courses
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Have a San Mateo County Library card
2. Visit smcl.org/get-calm
3. Follow instructions to create or link Calm account
4. Access Calm via web browser or mobile app
5. Enjoy unlimited access while program continues

programs.name: Discover & Go Museum Passes
programs.description: Free/discounted museum tickets and passes via library-partner access
programs.fullDescription: Discover & Go connects library cardholders with free and discounted admission to California museums, zoos, aquariums, and cultural institutions.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free or reduced admission to 100+ cultural institutions
- Museums, zoos, aquariums, gardens, and more
- Passes cover varying group sizes
- Available at participating libraries statewide
- New passes released regularly
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Check if your library participates at discoverandgo.org
2. Log in with your library card
3. Browse available passes
4. Reserve a pass for your preferred date
5. Print or save pass to mobile device
6. Present pass at venue for entry

programs.name: Hoopla Digital
programs.description: Free ebooks, audiobooks, music, movies, and TV shows
programs.fullDescription: Hoopla is a digital media service that allows library cardholders to borrow movies, TV shows, music, ebooks, audiobooks, and comics for free.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Streaming movies and TV shows
- Music albums
- Ebooks and audiobooks
- Comics and graphic novels
- No waitlistsinstant access
- Monthly borrowing limit varies by library
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Check if your library offers Hoopla
2. Download the Hoopla app or visit hoopladigital.com
3. Create an account using your library card
4. Browse and borrow content instantly
5. Content auto-returns after lending period

programs.name: Kanopy
programs.description: Free streaming of films and documentaries for library cardholders
programs.fullDescription: Kanopy is a free video streaming service for library cardholders offering thoughtful entertainment including films, documentaries, and educational content.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Thousands of films and documentaries
- Criterion Collection films
- Independent and international cinema
- Great Courses educational videos
- PBS documentaries
- Monthly credit system (varies by library)
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Check if your library offers Kanopy
2. Visit kanopy.com and find your library
3. Sign up with your library card
4. Stream on web, mobile, or TV apps
5. Credits refresh monthly

programs.name: New York Times Digital Access
programs.description: Complimentary 72-hour digital access to The New York Times online (articles, cooking, games, archives)
programs.fullDescription: California State Library provides free digital access to The New York Times for all Californians through participating public libraries.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Full access to NYTimes.com
- New York Times Cooking
- New York Times Games (Wordle, crosswords)
- Archives back to 1851
- 72-hour passes, renewable unlimited times
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit your library's website or the State Library's NYT page
2. Click the link to access the New York Times
3. Create a free NYT account or log in
4. Enjoy 72 hours of full access
5. Return to library site to renew when pass expires

programs.name: SFPL eLibrary
programs.description: Free access to ebooks, audiobooks, magazines, newspapers, movies, music, learning courses, research databases, and more with SF library card
programs.fullDescription: San Francisco Public Library's eLibrary provides free digital access to ebooks, audiobooks, databases, learning courses, and streaming content.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Ebooks and audiobooks (Libby, OverDrive)
- Digital magazines and newspapers
- Streaming movies and music
- LinkedIn Learning courses
- Research databases
- Language learning (Mango Languages)
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Get a San Francisco Public Library card (free for residents)
2. Visit sfpl.org/elibrary
3. Browse available digital resources
4. Sign in with your library card
5. Access content on computer or mobile devices

programs.name: SF Digital Collections
programs.description: Free access to archival photographs, manuscripts, documents, maps, ephemera, and audiovisual materials from digitized and born-digital collections
programs.fullDescription: San Francisco's digital collections provide free access to digitized historical photos, documents, manuscripts, and audiovisual materials from the city's archives.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Historical photographs of San Francisco
- Manuscripts and archival documents
- Maps and ephemera
- Audiovisual materials
- Born-digital collections
- Free to browse without library card
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit digitalsf.org
2. Browse or search collections
3. View and download materials for free
4. No library card required for access

programs.name: Open Library
programs.description: Free access to millions of books including ebooks to borrow, with goal to provide one web page for every book ever published
programs.fullDescription: Open Library is a project of the Internet Archive that provides free access to millions of books, with the goal of creating one web page for every book ever published.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Millions of free ebooks
- Borrowing system for in-copyright books
- Read online or download
- Multiple formats available
- Community-contributed book data
- Connect with your local library card
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit openlibrary.org
2. Create a free account (or use Internet Archive, Google, or library card)
3. Browse or search for books
4. Read online or borrow ebooks
5. Return borrowed books to allow others to read

programs.name: Libby by OverDrive
programs.description: Free ebooks, audiobooks, and magazines from your local library delivered to your phone or tablet
programs.fullDescription: Libby is the free reading app from OverDrive that connects library cardholders to their library's collection of ebooks, audiobooks, and magazines.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Ebooks from your library's collection
- Audiobooks for on-the-go listening
- Digital magazines
- Sync across devices
- Read offline
- Works with multiple library cards
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Download the free Libby app (iOS or Android)
2. Open the app and find your library
3. Sign in with your library card number
4. Browse and borrow from your library's collection
5. Books automatically returnno late fees

programs.name: California Digital Newspaper Collection
programs.description: Free access to digitized California newspapers from 1846 to present
programs.fullDescription: The California Digital Newspaper Collection provides free access to digitized California newspapers from 1846 to the present for historical research.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Digitized California newspapers from 1846-present
- Searchable full text
- Historical newspapers from across the state
- Free to access without library card
- High-quality scans of original pages
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit cdnc.ucr.edu
2. Search by keyword, date, or location
3. Browse available newspaper titles
4. View and download pages for free
5. No registration or library card required

programs.name: Career Online High School
programs.description: Free accredited high school diploma, career certificate, and career portfolio including resume and cover letter with extensive career development support
programs.fullDescription: Career Online High School is a free program through participating California libraries that allows adults to earn an accredited high school diploma and career certificate.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Accredited high school diploma
- Career certificate in your chosen field
- Career portfolio with resume and cover letter
- Academic coach support
- Self-paced online learning
- 8 career certificate tracks available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be 19+ years old (or 18 in some libraries)
2. Have a library card in good standing at a participating library
3. Complete the prerequisite courses (free orientation)
4. Apply to the program
5. If accepted, complete coursework online
6. Graduate with diploma and career certificate

programs.name: Online Archive of California
programs.description: Free access to detailed descriptions of primary resource collections from over 200 libraries, archives, historical societies, and museums throughout California
programs.fullDescription: The Online Archive of California provides free access to finding aids and primary source collections from over 200 California libraries, archives, and museums.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Finding aids to archival collections
- Primary source materials
- Collections from 200+ institutions
- Photographs and documents
- Historical records
- Free to search and browse
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit oac.cdlib.org
2. Search or browse collections by topic or institution
3. Find detailed descriptions of archival materials
4. Identify materials of interest
5. Contact holding institution for access to originals

programs.name: Alameda County Library Digital Resources
programs.description: Free digital resources including ebooks, audiobooks, databases, and online learning with Alameda County library card
programs.fullDescription: Alameda County Library provides free digital resources including ebooks, audiobooks, databases, and online learning for cardholders.
programs.whatTheyOffer:

- Streaming video and music
- Online databases and research tools
- Learning platforms (LinkedIn Learning, etc.)
- Magazines and newspapers
- Language learning resources
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Get an Alameda County Library card (free for residents)
2. Visit aclibrary.org/resource
3. Browse available digital resources
4. Sign in with your library card
5. Access content on any device

programs.description: Free digital resources including ebooks, audiobooks, databases, and online learning with Oakland library card

programs.name: Peninsula Library System E-Services
programs.description: Free digital resources and e-services for Peninsula Library System cardholders
programs.fullDescription: Peninsula Library System provides e-services and digital resources for cardholders from member libraries throughout San Mateo County.
programs.whatTheyOffer:

2. Visit plsinfo.org/e-services
3. Browse available resources
4. Sign in with your library card
5. Access content online

programs.name: Contra Costa County Library Digital Resources
programs.description: Free digital resources including ebooks, audiobooks, databases, and online learning with Contra Costa County library card
programs.fullDescription: Contra Costa County Library provides free digital resources including ebooks, audiobooks, streaming media, and learning platforms for cardholders.

programs.name: San Francisco Public Library Services
programs.description: Free library services including digital resources, programs, and community offerings with SF library card
programs.fullDescription: San Francisco Public Library offers a wide range of free services and programs beyond just books, including digital resources, programs, and community offerings.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Digital resources (eBooks, streaming, databases)
- Technology lending (laptops, WiFi hotspots)
- Free programs and events
- Homework help and tutoring
- Job search assistance
- Social worker services
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Get a San Francisco Public Library card (free)
2. Visit sfpl.org/services
3. Explore available services
4. Many services available online or in-person
5. Some programs require registration

programs.name: Santa Clara County Library Digital Resources
programs.description: Free digital resources including ebooks, audiobooks, databases, and online learning with Santa Clara County library card
programs.fullDescription: Santa Clara County Library District offers free digital resources including ebooks, audiobooks, streaming content, and online learning for cardholders.

programs.description: Free digital resources including ebooks, audiobooks, databases, and online learning with Sonoma County library card
programs.fullDescription: Sonoma County Library provides free eLibrary resources including ebooks, audiobooks, streaming content, and online learning for all cardholders.

programs.name: Solano County Library 24/7 Digital Library
programs.description: Free 24/7 digital resources including ebooks, audiobooks, databases, and online learning with Solano County library card
programs.fullDescription: Solano County Library provides 24/7 digital library resources including ebooks, audiobooks, streaming media, and online learning for cardholders.

- Streaming video and music

4. Sign in with your library card

programs.name: Napa County Library Databases
programs.description: Free access to research databases and digital resources with Napa County library card
programs.fullDescription: Napa County Library provides free access to research databases and digital resources for all cardholders.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Research databases
- Ebooks and audiobooks
- Digital magazines and newspapers
- Learning resources
- Consumer and business information
- Genealogy databases
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Get a Napa County Library card (free for residents)
2. Visit the library's databases page
3. Browse available resources
4. Sign in with your library card
5. Access content on any device

programs.name: Banfield Foundation - Pet Owner Resources
programs.description: Comprehensive directory of financial assistance programs, pet food banks, low-cost vet services, and emergency resources
programs.fullDescription: The Banfield Foundation is a nonprofit that helps pets and the people who love them by providing resources, grants, and support to pet owners facing financial hardship.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Comprehensive directory of financial assistance programs
- Pet food bank locations nationwide
- Low-cost veterinary service locator
- Emergency pet care resources
- Information on keeping pets during housing transitions
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit the Banfield Foundation website
2. Use the resource directory to find assistance in your area
3. Filter by type of help needed (food, vet care, housing, etc.)
4. Contact listed organizations directly for assistance

programs.name: Berkeley-East Bay Humane Society - Spay the Bay
programs.description: Low-cost spay/neuter and vaccinations
programs.fullDescription: Berkeley-East Bay Humane Society's Spay the Bay program provides affordable spay/neuter services to help reduce pet overpopulation in the East Bay.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Low-cost spay and neuter surgeries
- Vaccinations at reduced prices
- Microchipping services
- Services for cats and dogs
- Additional discounts for low-income residents
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit the Spay the Bay website
2. Check eligibility for low-income discounts (if applicable)
3. Schedule an appointment online or by phone
4. Bring your pet to the scheduled appointment
5. Pay the reduced fee at time of service

programs.name: HSSV Pet Pantry
programs.description: Free pet food for Santa Clara County residents experiencing financial hardship; pick up every 30 days
programs.fullDescription: The Humane Society Silicon Valley's Pet Pantry program helps families keep their pets by providing free pet food during times of financial hardship.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free dog and cat food
- Pet supplies when available
- No proof of income required
- Pick up every 30 days
- Helps families avoid surrendering pets due to cost
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a Santa Clara County resident
2. Visit the HSSV Pet Pantry during distribution hours
3. Bring ID showing Santa Clara County address
4. Receive up to 30 days of food per visit
5. Return monthly as needed

programs.name: Humane World
programs.description: Comprehensive directory of pet financial assistance programs and payment plans
programs.fullDescription: Humane World provides a comprehensive directory of resources for pet owners who are struggling to afford their pet's care, helping keep families and pets together.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Directory of pet financial assistance programs
- List of veterinary payment plan providers
- Pet insurance information
- Low-cost vet clinic locator
- Resources organized by state and type of assistance
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit the Humane World website
2. Navigate to the financial assistance section
3. Browse resources by location or type of help needed
4. Contact listed organizations directly

programs.name: Joybound People & Pets - Community Veterinary Care
programs.description: Low-cost medical care for dogs and cats for eligible residents
programs.fullDescription: Joybound People & Pets (formerly Tony La Russa's ARF) provides low-cost veterinary care to help Contra Costa County residents keep their pets healthy.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Low-cost medical exams and treatments
- Vaccinations at reduced prices
- Basic diagnostic services
- Care for dogs and cats
- Income-based pricing available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a Contra Costa County resident
2. Contact Joybound to verify eligibility
3. Provide proof of income if applying for reduced rates
4. Schedule appointment for your pet
5. Pay reduced fee at time of service

programs.name: Joybound People & Pets - Free Pet Food
programs.description: Free pet food for residents who need assistance
programs.fullDescription: Joybound's pet food assistance program helps Contra Costa County families keep their pets by providing free food during financial hardship.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free dog food
- Free cat food
- Pet supplies when available
- No-judgment assistance
- Helps prevent pet surrender due to cost
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a Contra Costa County resident
2. Contact Joybound to request assistance
3. Provide basic information about your pets
4. Arrange pickup or delivery of food

programs.name: Joybound People & Pets - Free Vaccination Clinics
programs.description: Free pet vaccination clinics at locations across Contra Costa County
programs.fullDescription: Joybound holds free vaccination clinics throughout Contra Costa County to help ensure all pets have access to essential preventive care.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free rabies vaccinations
- Free DHPP/FVRCP vaccines
- Microchipping at low or no cost
- No appointment needed at clinics
- Multiple clinic locations across the county
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Check the Joybound website for upcoming clinic dates and locations
2. Bring your pet to the clinic during scheduled hours
3. No appointment or proof of income required
4. Wait in line for service (first come, first served)

programs.name: Joybound People & Pets - Pet Safety Net
programs.description: Emergency resources to prevent pet surrender including food, vet care assistance, and supplies
programs.fullDescription: Joybound's Pet Safety Net provides emergency resources to help families keep their pets during times of crisis or financial hardship.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Emergency pet food assistance
- Veterinary care financial assistance
- Pet supplies (leashes, bowls, beds)
- Temporary foster care during emergencies
- Counseling to prevent pet surrender
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a Contra Costa County resident
2. Contact Joybound to explain your situation
3. Staff will assess needs and available resources
4. Receive assistance based on availability and need

programs.name: Joybound People & Pets - Spay/Neuter Clinic
programs.description: Low-cost spay/neuter services
programs.fullDescription: Joybound offers low-cost spay and neuter services to help reduce pet overpopulation and keep pets healthy.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Low-cost spay surgeries
- Low-cost neuter surgeries
- Services for dogs and cats
- Additional discounts for income-qualified residents
- Pre-surgery health check included
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Contact Joybound to schedule an appointment
2. Provide proof of income for discounted rates (if applicable)
3. Follow pre-surgery instructions
4. Bring pet to scheduled appointment
5. Pay reduced fee at time of service

programs.name: Marin Humane Society - Pet Care Assistance
programs.description: Pet care assistance for low-income seniors, people living with HIV/AIDS, and hospice recipients; Pet Meals on Wheels
programs.fullDescription: Marin Humane Society provides pet care assistance to help vulnerable Marin County residents keep and care for their pets.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Pet Meals on Wheels (food delivery for homebound seniors)
- Financial assistance for veterinary care
- Pet food pantry
- Services for people living with HIV/AIDS
- Support for hospice recipients
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Contact Marin Humane Society to inquire about assistance
2. Must be a Marin County resident
3. Explain your situation and needs
4. Provide documentation as required (age, income, medical status)
5. Receive assistance based on program eligibility
programs.address: 171 Bel Marin Keys Blvd, Novato, CA 94949

programs.name: Muttville Senior Dog Rescue - Cuddle Club
programs.description: Free cuddle time events with senior dogs for adults 62+ (no adoption required)
programs.fullDescription: Muttville's Cuddle Club brings the joy of dogs to seniors 62+ through free events where they can spend time with gentle senior dogsno adoption required.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free cuddle time with senior dogs
- Social events for seniors 62+
- Therapeutic animal interaction
- No commitment or adoption required
- Events at senior centers and Muttville's office
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be 62 years or older
2. Check Muttville's website for upcoming Cuddle Club events
3. Register for an event if required
4. Attend and enjoy time with the dogs
5. No cost or obligation

programs.name: Muttville Senior Dog Rescue - Seniors for Seniors
programs.description: Free adoption of senior dogs (7+ years) for seniors 62+
programs.fullDescription: Muttville's Seniors for Seniors program offers free adoptions of senior dogs (7+ years) to seniors 62 and older, helping both seniors and dogs find companionship.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free adoption of senior dogs (7 years and older)
- All dogs are spayed/neutered and vaccinated
- Behavioral assessment completed
- Ongoing support after adoption
- Return policy if it doesn't work out
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be 62 years or older
2. Visit Muttville's website to view adoptable senior dogs
3. Complete an adoption application
4. Meet with dogs at Muttville or adoption events
5. Take home your new companion at no cost

programs.name: Peninsula Humane Society - Mobile Spay/Neuter Van
programs.description: Free spay/neuter
programs.fullDescription: Peninsula Humane Society's mobile spay/neuter van travels throughout San Mateo County providing accessible, low-cost sterilization services.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free or low-cost spay/neuter surgeries
- Services for cats and dogs
- Mobile van visits different neighborhoods
- Additional services may include vaccines
- Income-qualified pricing available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Check the PHS website for mobile van schedule and locations
2. Call to schedule an appointment
3. Provide proof of income for free services (if applicable)
4. Bring pet to scheduled location on appointment day

programs.name: Peninsula Humane Society SPCA Low-Cost Vaccine Clinics
programs.description: Low-cost vaccinations, microchipping, nail trims
programs.fullDescription: Peninsula Humane Society & SPCA offers regular low-cost vaccine clinics providing essential preventive care for dogs and cats.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Low-cost vaccinations (rabies, DHPP, FVRCP)
- Microchipping services
- Nail trims
- No appointment needed for most services
- Both dog and cat services available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Check the PHS website for vaccine clinic schedule
2. Arrive during clinic hours (first come, first served)
3. Bring pet and payment (cash or card)
4. Complete brief intake form
5. Wait for services

programs.name: Pet Help Finder
programs.description: Database of low-cost vet services, financial assistance, and pet resources by location
programs.fullDescription: Pet Help Finder is a searchable database that helps pet owners locate low-cost veterinary services and financial assistance programs by zip code.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Searchable database of low-cost vet clinics
- Financial assistance program listings
- Pet food bank locations
- Emergency assistance resources
- Results customized by location
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit pethelpfinder.org
2. Enter your zip code
3. Select the type of help you need
4. Browse results for your area
5. Contact providers directly for services

programs.name: Pets in Need - Low-Cost Vet Services
programs.description: Low-cost vet care, spay/neuter, vaccinations, microchipping, and more
programs.fullDescription: Pets in Need operates a community veterinary clinic in Redwood City providing affordable care to help families keep their pets healthy.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Low-cost wellness exams
- Spay and neuter surgeries
- Vaccinations and preventive care
- Microchipping
- Basic medical treatments
- Additional discounts for income-qualified
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit the Pets in Need website or call for appointment
2. Schedule your pet's appointment
3. Bring proof of income for discounted rates (if applicable)
4. Pay reduced fees at time of service

programs.name: Pets of the Homeless
programs.description: Free veterinary care and pet food assistance for people experiencing homelessness
programs.fullDescription: Pets of the Homeless is a nonprofit providing free veterinary care and pet food to pets of people experiencing homelessness.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free veterinary care through participating providers
- Free pet food at distribution sites
- Emergency veterinary assistance
- Directory of homeless-friendly pet resources
- No proof of homelessness required at most sites
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit petsofthehomeless.org
2. Use the locator to find participating providers near you
3. Contact the provider directly for services
4. Bring your pet during operating hours
5. Most services are first come, first served

programs.name: San Francisco SPCA - Community Clinic
programs.description: Affordable preventative care, including vaccines, parasite protection, and treatment for minor conditions
programs.fullDescription: The SF SPCA's Community Clinic provides affordable preventative care to help all San Francisco pets stay healthy.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Affordable wellness exams
- Vaccinations at reduced prices
- Parasite prevention (flea, tick, heartworm)
- Treatment for minor conditions
- Microchipping services
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Call or book online for an appointment
2. Income verification not required but discounts available
3. Bring your pet to the clinic at scheduled time
4. Pay affordable fees at time of service

programs.name: San Francisco SPCA - Spay/Neuter
programs.description: Affordable spay/neuter services with tiered fees for eligible SF residents
programs.fullDescription: The SF SPCA offers affordable spay and neuter services with tiered pricing to make sterilization accessible to all San Francisco residents.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Tiered pricing based on ability to pay
- Spay and neuter for dogs and cats
- All surgeries include pain medication
- Post-operative care instructions
- Some free services for SF residents in need
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a San Francisco resident
2. Call or visit the website to learn about pricing tiers
3. Schedule an appointment
4. Bring proof of SF residency
5. Pay based on your tier at time of service

programs.name: SF Aid for Animals (SFAFA)
programs.description: Financial support for urgent vet services for Bay Area residents with participating veterinary hospitals
programs.fullDescription: SF Aid for Animals provides financial assistance for urgent veterinary care to low-income Bay Area residents, helping them avoid having to surrender or euthanize pets due to cost.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Financial grants for urgent veterinary care
- Assistance with life-saving procedures
- Works with participating veterinary hospitals
- Covers portion of vet bills based on need
- Helps prevent economic euthanasia
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Must be a Bay Area resident
2. Must demonstrate financial need
3. Pet must be treated at a participating veterinary hospital
4. Apply through the SFAFA website
5. Hospital will work with SFAFA on payment

programs.name: The Pet Fund
programs.description: Financial assistance for non-basic, non-emergency veterinary care (has waitlist)
programs.fullDescription: The Pet Fund provides financial assistance for non-basic, non-emergency veterinary care to pet owners who cannot afford treatment.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Financial assistance for non-emergency vet care
- Help with ongoing treatment costs
- Covers conditions like diabetes, cancer treatment, etc.
- Does NOT cover routine care or emergencies
- Waitlist may apply
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit thepetfund.com to apply
2. Complete the application form
3. Provide documentation of financial need
4. Provide veterinary estimate for needed care
5. Wait for approval (waitlist common)
6. If approved, funds sent to veterinarian

programs.name: Vet Billing - Payment Plans
programs.description: Directory of veterinarians offering payment plans or financing options
programs.fullDescription: Vet Billing maintains a directory of veterinary practices that offer payment plans or financing options, helping pet owners manage veterinary costs over time.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Directory of vets offering payment plans
- Information on veterinary financing options
- Searchable by location
- Details on each vet's payment policies
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit vetbilling.com
2. Enter your location to search
3. Browse list of participating veterinarians
4. Contact vets directly to discuss payment options
5. Arrange payment plan at time of service

programs.name: VETCO Clinics
programs.description: Affordable vaccinations and basic pet health services at various locations
programs.fullDescription: VETCO operates walk-in vaccination clinics inside Petco stores, providing convenient and affordable preventive care for dogs and cats.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Affordable vaccinations
- Microchipping services
- Heartworm testing
- Flea and tick prevention
- No appointment needed
- Located inside Petco stores
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit vetcoclinics.com to find a clinic near you
2. Check the schedule for your local Petco
3. Walk in during clinic hours (no appointment needed)
4. Complete a brief health form
5. Pay affordable fees at time of service

programs.name: VIP Petcare
programs.description: Walk-in weekend clinics offering vaccinations, microchipping, testing, flea/tick control (no exam fee)
programs.fullDescription: VIP Petcare provides walk-in wellness clinics at pet stores throughout Northern California, offering affordable preventive care without the need for an appointment.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Walk-in vaccination clinics
- Microchipping
- Health testing (heartworm, FeLV/FIV)
- Flea and tick prevention
- No exam fee for most services
- Weekend hours available
programs.howToGetIt:
1. Visit vippetcare.com to find a clinic location
2. Check the schedule for your preferred location
3. Walk in during clinic hours (no appointment needed)
4. Bring your pet and wait for service
5. Pay at time of service

programs.name: America the Beautiful  NPS Pass
programs.description: The National Park Service offers lifetime and annual passes providing access to over 2,000 federal recreation sites across the United States, including national parks, wildlife refuges, and forests.
programs.fullDescription: The National Park Service offers lifetime and annual passes providing access to over 2,000 federal recreation sites across the United States, including national parks, wildlife refuges, and forests.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Senior Pass (62+): $80 lifetime or $20 annual pass
- Military Pass: Free annual pass for active duty and dependents
- Access Pass: Free lifetime pass for persons with permanent disabilities
- All passes cover entrance fees and standard amenity fees
programs.howToGetIt: Purchase online at recreation.gov, by phone at 1-888-275-8747, or in person at any federal recreation site that charges entrance fees. Access Pass requires documentation of permanent disability.

programs.name: California State Parks Adventure Pass
programs.description: California State Parks offers free access to fourth graders and their families as part of the Every Kid Outdoors initiative, encouraging young people to explore the state's natural and cultural heritage.
programs.fullDescription: California State Parks offers free access to fourth graders and their families as part of the Every Kid Outdoors initiative, encouraging young people to explore the state's natural and cultural heritage.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free day-use passes to 54 participating state parks
- Valid for fourth graders at California public schools
- Covers the student and their family members
programs.howToGetIt: Apply online through Reserve California. Fourth graders at public schools can register with their school information to receive passes.

programs.name: California State Parks Disabled Discount Pass
programs.description: California State Parks provides lifetime access to residents with permanent disabilities, making outdoor recreation more accessible and affordable for all Californians.
programs.fullDescription: California State Parks provides lifetime access to residents with permanent disabilities, making outdoor recreation more accessible and affordable for all Californians.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Lifetime pass for individuals with permanent disabilities
- 50% discount on vehicle day-use fees
- 50% discount on family camping fees
- 50% discount on boat-use fees at state parks
programs.howToGetIt: Apply online or by mail through California State Parks. You'll need to provide proof of California residency and documentation of permanent disability from a licensed physician or government agency.

programs.name: California State Parks Distinguished Veteran Pass
programs.description: California honors its veterans with free lifetime access to state parks for those who meet distinguished service requirements, recognizing their sacrifice and service to our country.
programs.fullDescription: California honors its veterans with free lifetime access to state parks for those who meet distinguished service requirements, recognizing their sacrifice and service to our country.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free lifetime pass to California state parks
- Covers vehicle day-use fees at all state parks
- Includes free camping at all state park campgrounds
- Free boat-use fees at participating locations
programs.howToGetIt: Apply through California State Parks with proof of honorable discharge and eligibility. Qualifying criteria include Medal of Honor recipients, former POWs, and veterans with service-connected disabilities rated 50% or higher.

programs.name: Golden Bear Pass
programs.description: California State Parks offers the Golden Bear Pass to ensure that cost is not a barrier to enjoying the state's natural treasures, providing free access to income-eligible residents and seniors.
programs.fullDescription: California State Parks offers the Golden Bear Pass to ensure that cost is not a barrier to enjoying the state's natural treasures, providing free access to income-eligible residents and seniors.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free vehicle day-use access to many California state parks
- Valid for one calendar year
- Available to CalWORKs, SSI, and Tribal TANF recipients
- Also available to seniors 62+ below income threshold
programs.howToGetIt: Apply online at the California State Parks website. You'll need to show proof of enrollment in CalWORKs, SSI, or Tribal TANF, or proof of age 62+ with income documentation.

programs.name: Senior Golden Bear Pass
programs.description: California State Parks offers discounted annual passes for seniors age 62 and over, providing access to the state's beautiful parks, beaches, and historic sites during off-peak periods.
programs.fullDescription: California State Parks offers discounted annual passes for seniors age 62 and over, providing access to the state's beautiful parks, beaches, and historic sites during off-peak periods.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Annual pass for seniors 62+ and their spouse/domestic partner
- Free vehicle day-use entry to many state parks
- Valid during non-peak season only (check specific park schedules)
programs.howToGetIt: Purchase online or at any California State Park entrance station. You'll need proof of age (62 or older). The pass is $25 per year.

programs.name: Museums for All
programs.description: Museums for All is a national program connecting low-income families with cultural institutions, ensuring that financial barriers don't prevent anyone from experiencing the enrichment museums offer.
programs.fullDescription: Museums for All is a national program connecting low-income families with cultural institutions, ensuring that financial barriers don't prevent anyone from experiencing the enrichment museums offer.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free or reduced admission ($3 or less per person)
- Admission for EBT cardholder plus up to 4 guests
- Access to 1,700+ participating museums nationwide
- Includes science centers, children's museums, art museums, and more
programs.howToGetIt: Visit any participating museum and present your EBT (SNAP/CalFresh) card along with a photo ID at the admissions desk. No reservation needed at most locations, but some may require advance booking.

programs.name: Aquarium of the Bay
programs.description: Aquarium of the Bay is a nonprofit aquarium located on Pier 39 in San Francisco, dedicated to protecting, restoring, and inspiring conservation of San Francisco Bay and its watershed. The aquarium features over 20,000 local marine animals including sharks, rays, jellyfish, and river otters.
programs.fullDescription: Aquarium of the Bay is a nonprofit aquarium located on Pier 39 in San Francisco, dedicated to protecting, restoring, and inspiring conservation of San Francisco Bay and its watershed. The aquarium features over 20,000 local marine animals including sharks, rays, jellyfish, and river otters.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Bay Area residents: $5 off general admission with local ID
- Military discount: 10% off for active duty, veterans, and families
- EBT/Museums for All: Reduced admission (check current rates)
- Children under 3: Free admission
- Annual passes available with unlimited visits
programs.howToGetIt: Purchase tickets at the door or online. Bring valid Bay Area ID for local discount, military ID for military discount, or EBT card for Museums for All pricing. Discounts cannot be combined.
programs.address: PIER 39, The Embarcadero & Beach Street, San Francisco, CA 94133

programs.name: Asian Art Museum
programs.description: The Asian Art Museum of San Francisco houses one of the world's most comprehensive collections of Asian art, spanning 6,000 years of history with over 18,000 artworks from across the Asian continent.
programs.fullDescription: The Asian Art Museum of San Francisco houses one of the world's most comprehensive collections of Asian art, spanning 6,000 years of history with over 18,000 artworks from across the Asian continent.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free admission: First Sundays each month for everyone
- Museums for All: $1 admission for EBT cardholders + guests
- Seniors (65+): $12 admission (regularly $20)
- Students with ID: $12 admission
- Military/Veterans: Free admission with valid ID
- Children under 6: Always free
- SF residents: Free admission on select Thursdays
programs.howToGetIt: Visit the museum and present your EBT card, student ID, military ID, or proof of age at the admissions desk. Check the website for free day schedules and any advance reservation requirements.

programs.name: Bay Area Discovery Museum
programs.description: The Bay Area Discovery Museum is a hands-on children's museum nestled at the foot of the Golden Gate Bridge in Sausalito, featuring indoor and outdoor exhibits designed to spark creativity and curiosity in children ages 0-10.
programs.fullDescription: The Bay Area Discovery Museum is a hands-on children's museum nestled at the foot of the Golden Gate Bridge in Sausalito, featuring indoor and outdoor exhibits designed to spark creativity and curiosity in children ages 0-10.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- EBT/WIC cardholders: $5 admission per person
- Caregivers of visitors with disabilities: Free admission
- Pay-What-You-Can days: Admission at any price you choose
- Members: Unlimited free visits year-round
- Children under 1: Free admission
- Regular admission: $18 per person
programs.howToGetIt: For EBT/WIC discount, show your benefits card at the admissions desk. Check the museum website for scheduled Pay-What-You-Can days. Advance reservations recommended for all visits.

programs.name: California Academy of Sciences
programs.description: The California Academy of Sciences in Golden Gate Park is a world-class scientific and cultural institution featuring a natural history museum, aquarium, planetarium, and rainforest all under one living roof.
programs.fullDescription: The California Academy of Sciences in Golden Gate Park is a world-class scientific and cultural institution featuring a natural history museum, aquarium, planetarium, and rainforest all under one living roof.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Museums for All: $3 per person with EBT card
- SF Resident Free Days: Free admission for SF residents (check schedule)
- Neighborhood Free Days: Free for specific SF zip codes (rotating)
- Children under 3: Always free
- Regular admission: $34-39 for adults
programs.howToGetIt: For Museums for All, present your EBT card and photo ID at the admissions desk. For SF Resident Free Days, bring proof of residence. Reservations are required for all visits - book online in advance.
programs.address: 55 Music Concourse Drive, San Francisco, CA 94118

programs.name: Chabot Space & Science Center
programs.description: Chabot Space & Science Center in the Oakland hills features interactive space science exhibits, planetarium shows, and three historic telescopes offering free public viewing nights. The center inspires curiosity about the universe and our place in it.
programs.fullDescription: Chabot Space & Science Center in the Oakland hills features interactive space science exhibits, planetarium shows, and three historic telescopes offering free public viewing nights. The center inspires curiosity about the universe and our place in it.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- EBT cardholders: $5 admission per person
- Free telescope viewing: Friday and Saturday evenings (weather permitting)
- Children under 2: Free admission
- Members: Unlimited visits plus guest discounts
- Regular admission: $24 for adults, $18 for children
programs.howToGetIt: Show your EBT card at the admissions desk for reduced admission. Telescope viewing is free and open to the public on clear Friday and Saturday nights - no reservation needed.

programs.name: Cartoon Art Museum
programs.description: The Cartoon Art Museum is one of only a handful of museums in the United States dedicated to the art of cartoons, animation, and comics. Located in San Francisco's Fisherman's Wharf, it celebrates the history and cultural impact of cartoon art.
programs.fullDescription: The Cartoon Art Museum is one of only a handful of museums in the United States dedicated to the art of cartoons, animation, and comics. Located in San Francisco's Fisherman's Wharf, it celebrates the history and cultural impact of cartoon art.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- EBT/SNAP/Medi-Cal: Free or reduced admission
- Pay-What-You-Wish days: Admission at your chosen price
- Students with ID: $8 admission
- Seniors (65+): $8 admission
- Military: Discounted admission with valid ID
- Children under 5: Free
- Regular admission: $12 for adults
programs.howToGetIt: Present your benefits card, student ID, or military ID at admission. Check the museum website for Pay-What-You-Wish day schedule. Advance tickets recommended but walk-ins welcome.

programs.name: Children's Creativity Museum
programs.description: The Children's Creativity Museum in San Francisco's Yerba Buena Gardens is an interactive arts and technology museum for children ages 2-12, featuring hands-on exhibits that encourage creativity through music, animation, and digital media.
programs.fullDescription: The Children's Creativity Museum in San Francisco's Yerba Buena Gardens is an interactive arts and technology museum for children ages 2-12, featuring hands-on exhibits that encourage creativity through music, animation, and digital media.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Museums for All: Reduced admission with EBT card (cardholder + guests)
- Must have at least one child in the group
- Children under 2: Free admission
- Regular admission: $16 per person
programs.howToGetIt: Present your physical EBT or SNAP benefits card along with a photo ID at the admissions desk. Groups must include at least one child to qualify. Reservations recommended.

programs.name: Children's Discovery Museum
programs.description: Children's Discovery Museum of San Jose is one of the largest children's museums in the country, featuring interactive exhibits that inspire children to explore, question, and discover the world around them.
programs.fullDescription: Children's Discovery Museum of San Jose is one of the largest children's museums in the country, featuring interactive exhibits that inspire children to explore, question, and discover the world around them.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Museums for All: $5 per person for up to 4 people
- Valid for EBT, BIC, or WIC cardholders
- Children under 1: Free admission
- Regular admission: $18 per person
programs.howToGetIt: Present your EBT, BIC (Benefits Identification Card), or WIC card at the admissions desk. Discount applies to cardholder plus up to 3 additional guests. Advance reservations recommended.

programs.name: Children's Fairyland
programs.description: Children's Fairyland is a whimsical storybook theme park on the shores of Lake Merritt in Oakland, designed for children ages 0-8. As one of the first theme parks in America, it has delighted families since 1950 with its enchanting sets, live animals, and puppet shows.
programs.fullDescription: Children's Fairyland is a whimsical storybook theme park on the shores of Lake Merritt in Oakland, designed for children ages 0-8. As one of the first theme parks in America, it has delighted families since 1950 with its enchanting sets, live animals, and puppet shows.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- EBT/WIC cardholders: $5 admission per person
- Children under 1: Free admission
- Regular admission: $15 per person
- Annual passes available for frequent visitors
programs.howToGetIt: Present your EBT or WIC card at the admission booth. Discount applies to all members of your party. No advance reservation required but recommended on weekends and holidays.

programs.name: Exploratorium
programs.description: The Exploratorium is San Francisco's world-renowned museum of science, art, and human perception. Located on Pier 15, it features over 650 interactive exhibits that encourage hands-on exploration and discovery.
programs.fullDescription: The Exploratorium is San Francisco's world-renowned museum of science, art, and human perception. Located on Pier 15, it features over 650 interactive exhibits that encourage hands-on exploration and discovery.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- California PreK-12 public school teachers: Free admission
- Museums for All: $3 admission for up to 4 people
- Valid with EBT/SNAP, Medi-Cal, WIC, or Lifeline Pass
- After Dark (18+): $3 admission with qualifying card
- Discounted memberships: $39 Family, $19 Dual After Dark
- Must purchase at ticket window (not available online)
programs.howToGetIt: California PreK-12 public school teachers can apply for free admission online and bring teacher ID. For low-income discounts, visit the ticket window with your EBT, SNAP, Medi-Cal, WIC card, or Lifeline Pass. These discounts are not available for online purchases.
programs.address: Pier 15, The Embarcadero, San Francisco, CA 94111

programs.name: Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco
programs.description: The Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco comprise the de Young Museum in Golden Gate Park and the Legion of Honor in Lincoln Park. Together they house an encyclopedic collection spanning over 5,000 years of ancient and European art, American art, textiles, and more.
programs.fullDescription: The Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco comprise the de Young Museum in Golden Gate Park and the Legion of Honor in Lincoln Park. Together they house an encyclopedic collection spanning over 5,000 years of ancient and European art, American art, textiles, and more.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free Saturdays: Free for all Bay Area residents (proof required)
- Free First Tuesdays: Free admission for everyone
- Museums for All: $3 with EBT or Medi-Cal card
- Youth under 18: Always free
- College students with ID: Discounted admission
- Military/Veterans: Free with valid ID
- Seniors (65+): $12 admission
programs.howToGetIt: Bring Bay Area ID for Free Saturdays, EBT/Medi-Cal card for reduced admission, or other qualifying documentation. Check website for specific dates and any reservation requirements.
programs.address: 50 Hagiwara Tea Garden Drive, San Francisco, CA 94118 (de Young)

programs.name: Gardens of Golden Gate Park
programs.description: Golden Gate Park's gardens include the Conservatory of Flowers (a Victorian greenhouse with tropical plants), Japanese Tea Garden (the oldest public Japanese garden in the US), and San Francisco Botanical Garden (featuring 9,000 plant species from around the world).
programs.fullDescription: Golden Gate Park's gardens include the Conservatory of Flowers (a Victorian greenhouse with tropical plants), Japanese Tea Garden (the oldest public Japanese garden in the US), and San Francisco Botanical Garden (featuring 9,000 plant species from around the world).
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- SF Residents: Free admission to Botanical Garden with ID
- Veterans/Active Military: Free admission with ID
- Museums for All: Reduced admission with EBT card
- Free hours: Early morning entry at select gardens
- Children under 5: Free at all gardens
- Regular admission varies by garden ($10-15 adults)
programs.howToGetIt: Show SF proof of residency, military ID, or EBT card at the entrance. Visit early mornings for free admission hours at certain gardens. Check individual garden websites for current free hours and policies.

programs.name: Lawrence Hall of Science
programs.description: The Lawrence Hall of Science is UC Berkeley's public science center, perched in the hills above campus with stunning bay views. It offers hands-on exhibits, planetarium shows, and outdoor science activities for all ages.
programs.fullDescription: The Lawrence Hall of Science is UC Berkeley's public science center, perched in the hills above campus with stunning bay views. It offers hands-on exhibits, planetarium shows, and outdoor science activities for all ages.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- EBT cardholders: $1 admission per person
- Cal Day: Free admission (one day per year in April)
- Children under 3: Free admission
- UC Berkeley students/staff: Free with ID
- Regular admission: $16 adults, $13 children
programs.howToGetIt: Present your EBT card at the admissions desk. No limit on number of people in your party. Advance reservations recommended on weekends and during school breaks.

programs.name: Museum of the African Diaspora (MoAD)
programs.description: The Museum of the African Diaspora (MoAD) in San Francisco celebrates the history, art, and cultural contributions of people of African descent. Located in the Yerba Buena arts district, it features rotating contemporary art exhibitions and cultural programs.
programs.fullDescription: The Museum of the African Diaspora (MoAD) in San Francisco celebrates the history, art, and cultural contributions of people of African descent. Located in the Yerba Buena arts district, it features rotating contemporary art exhibitions and cultural programs.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Museums for All: $3 admission with EBT card
- Active Military: Free admission with valid ID
- Students with ID: $8 admission
- Seniors (65+): $8 admission
- Children under 5: Free admission
- Community/Free days: Check website for schedule
- Regular admission: $12 adults
programs.howToGetIt: Present your EBT card, military ID, student ID, or proof of age at the admissions desk. Check website for community free day schedules.

programs.name: Museum of Craft and Design
programs.description: The Museum of Craft and Design (MCD) in San Francisco's Dogpatch neighborhood explores the creative process through contemporary craft and design. It's the only museum in San Francisco devoted exclusively to craft and design.
programs.fullDescription: The Museum of Craft and Design (MCD) in San Francisco's Dogpatch neighborhood explores the creative process through contemporary craft and design. It's the only museum in San Francisco devoted exclusively to craft and design.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Free First Thursdays: Free admission for everyone
- EBT/Benefits cardholders: Free admission
- First responders: Free admission with ID
- Military: Free admission with ID
- Students with ID: $6 admission
- Seniors (65+): $6 admission
- Children under 6: Free admission
- Regular admission: $12 adults
programs.howToGetIt: Visit on First Thursday for free entry, or show your EBT card, military/first responder ID, student ID, or proof of age at admission. Walk-ins welcome.

programs.name: Oakland Museum of California
programs.description: The Oakland Museum of California (OMCA) is a multidisciplinary museum celebrating California's art, history, and natural sciences. Located near Lake Merritt, it features gardens, exhibitions, and the popular Friday Nights @ OMCA events.
programs.fullDescription: The Oakland Museum of California (OMCA) is a multidisciplinary museum celebrating California's art, history, and natural sciences. Located near Lake Merritt, it features gardens, exhibitions, and the popular Friday Nights @ OMCA events.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- EBT cardholders: $1 admission per person
- Free First Sundays: Free admission for everyone
- Children under 9: Free admission
- Friday Nights @ OMCA: Half-price admission with food trucks and live music
- Regular admission: $16 adults
programs.howToGetIt: Present your EBT card at the admissions desk for $1 admission any day. Visit on the first Sunday of each month for free entry. No reservations required for most visits.

programs.name: Oakland Zoo  Bay to Zoo
programs.description: Oakland Zoo is home to over 850 native and exotic animals on 100 acres in the Oakland hills. The zoo is committed to conservation and education, featuring the California Trail exhibit showcasing native wildlife.
programs.fullDescription: Oakland Zoo is home to over 850 native and exotic animals on 100 acres in the Oakland hills. The zoo is committed to conservation and education, featuring the California Trail exhibit showcasing native wildlife.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Bay to Zoo program: $5 admission for low-income families
- Must show qualifying documentation
- Children under 2: Free admission
- Regular admission: $28 adults, $22 children
programs.howToGetIt: Purchase Bay to Zoo tickets online or at the gate. You'll need to show documentation of participation in CalFresh, WIC, Medi-Cal, or similar assistance programs. Valid for cardholder and immediate family members.

programs.name: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA)
programs.description: SFMOMA is one of the largest museums of modern and contemporary art in the United States, featuring an expansive collection of painting, sculpture, photography, architecture, design, and media arts in its distinctive building in downtown San Francisco.
programs.fullDescription: SFMOMA is one of the largest museums of modern and contemporary art in the United States, featuring an expansive collection of painting, sculpture, photography, architecture, design, and media arts in its distinctive building in downtown San Francisco.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- Youth under 19: Always free
- Museums for All: $5 for SF residents with EBT/Medi-Cal
- Free days: Several free admission days throughout the year
- Military/Veterans: $5 admission with ID
- Discover & Go: Free passes through local libraries
- Regular admission: $30 adults
programs.howToGetIt: Youth enter free without reservation. For Museums for All, bring EBT or Medi-Cal card plus SF proof of residence. Check library for Discover & Go passes. Reserve tickets online for free days.

programs.name: San Jose Museum of Art
programs.description: The San Jose Museum of Art is the leading museum of modern and contemporary art in Silicon Valley, located in a beautiful historic building in downtown San Jose. It features rotating exhibitions and a growing permanent collection.
programs.fullDescription: The San Jose Museum of Art is the leading museum of modern and contemporary art in Silicon Valley, located in a beautiful historic building in downtown San Jose. It features rotating exhibitions and a growing permanent collection.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- EBT cardholders: Free admission
- Children under 6: Free admission
- First Fridays: Free admission for everyone (5-10pm)
- Students with ID: $5 admission
- Seniors (65+): $8 admission
- Regular admission: $12 adults
programs.howToGetIt: Present your EBT card at the admissions desk for free entry any day. No reservation required. Visit on First Friday evenings for free community nights with art activities and entertainment.
programs.address: 110 South Market Street, San Jose, CA 95113

programs.name: The Tech Interactive
programs.description: The Tech Interactive (formerly The Tech Museum) is a hands-on science and technology center in downtown San Jose. Featuring innovative exhibits on robotics, virtual reality, renewable energy, and more, it inspires the next generation of innovators.
programs.fullDescription: The Tech Interactive (formerly The Tech Museum) is a hands-on science and technology center in downtown San Jose. Featuring innovative exhibits on robotics, virtual reality, renewable energy, and more, it inspires the next generation of innovators.
programs.whatTheyOffer:
- EBT cardholders: $5 admission per person
- Children under 3: Free admission
- Regular admission: $32 adults, $27 children
- IMAX films: Additional fee
